I took the official Harvard Uni tour which is free and is conducted by the students of the Harvard running hourly from 10 am to 3 pm. It starts at the Harvard visitor info centre.
It was so fabulous , our guide Nathan doing his secnd year stats was superb. He told us Harvard history showed us completely around , unique heart wrenching stories of the Library and inside superstitions of Harvard Community which the community completely believes in.What a fabulous time I had, came back enriched.
From there I had food at one of the food trucks in the square outside Science Bldg and then went to their very fine Harvard Art Museum.
A day to cherish ...:):)

title: Had to see
text: While in Boston, we had to see Harvard University and we were not disappointed.  What a beautiful, historic campus!  We enjoyed strolling the grounds and feeling the anticipation as the summer school students arrived.

title: Great University
text: On of my friends works in the University as a professor so we had a private viewing of the Harvard campus ,what a great place to go or work in

title: Brings back fond memories
text: I got my graduate degree from Harvard over 40 years ago and I have only been back a few times since.  I loved going to the school back in the seventies and this visit brought back many great memories of my times there.   Harvard is a great school and a great attraction for the visitor.

title: America's Cambridge . . . IN Cambridge!
text: 25 acre campus, of which you will only need to see a small part to have the 'Harvard Experience'.  Educational home of 44+ Nobel laureates, several U.S. Presidents and hundreds of major contributors to both American and world civilisation.  Your experience will be different if you are there during the school year or over the summer months.  Take the T redline to Harvard/Cambridge.  Smith Campus Information Center is right around the corner on Dunster Street, and this is where you sign up for the free Student-led tour.  Of course if you wish, you can pay up to $20 per person through Viatour, Duck Tours and others.  You will see the highlights of both Harvard Yard and Harvard Square areas, such as Massachusetts Hall (where both John Adams and John Hancock bunked as freshmen) Memorial Hall, the statue of 'John Harvard' in front of University Hall (touch his leg for luck), Sever Hall, Widener Library and the Lampoon offices.  Entry is restricted to many locations due to campus security concerns.  In the Harvard Square area you will see the Plaza, Winthrop Park and Mount Auburn Street.  Tour ends near the Shop / Bookstore so you can get souvenirs.  Many eateries close by (though some tour versions include either a stop at the Harvard Museum of Natural History, or lunch at a restaurant called 'Fire and Ice'.  Enjoy!

title: OMG!
text: SO Harvard! Such a paradise for the nerd and non-nerd alike. Prestigious academia! Loved the Harvard Yard, and just walking amongst the Harvard vibe. Beware when getting your Harvard paraphernalia as it's very expensive!

title: an amazing campus to see
text: i visited this campus several times and every time i like it more. really gorgeous , and a feeling of serenity and great atmosphere

title: not a campus a whole town!
text: Hard to tell where Harvard begins or ends.  I kept asking which building belong to Harvard and my conclusion is that it is a whole city.  Nice yards and well kept monuments.  Adequate coffe shops and foodcourts.

title: Caught a show
text: Harvard opens it's doors for theater, music and art. We saw a quartet..for $2.00! We also caught Shakespeare's Hamlet for $8.00- both performances were high quality!

title: Worth wandering in
text: After all the years, it's still impressive to tour the campus.  The Yard is still interesting to wander and there have been some new additions that were interesting to see.  Didn't think there was land to build anything on but I guess they're constantly upgrading.

title: If you plan to visit, do sign up for the tour
text: If visiting Harvard is on your agenda, do sign up for the tour. The tour guide is very engaging and informative. They complete the tour in 45 minutes. Great campus and even more engaging history.

title: "I went to Harvard"
text: I joke with friends that I went there...and I did!  I walked thru the campus to the bookstore and purchased T-shirts for the kids.  Nice campus, but I did not see any cars parked in Harvard yard...lol  Just park benches with music in the trees.  (P.S.  I attended college in the Colorado).

title: campus tours are fantastic, thank you guys!!
text: Would recommend to book online prior to your visit; they fill up very quickly, especially during the summer time. I would recommend the tour for anyone visiting Boston - the University is a part of great American history.

title: Great Campus!
text: What a beautiful campus. I never thought it was so small. Great buildings and right in the heart of Cambridge.

title: truly the center of Cambridge
text: grand historic buildings dot this beautiful campus that predates our country by almost 150 years.  the tours are fun and informative.  great way to spend a morning.

title: Lovely campus with a long traditional history and academic achievements!
text:
We were here in the early morning (around 8am) as part of our day tour in Boston and this was the first stop of the day. Upon arrival, we were impressed with the campus, with satellite kind of clusters among academic schools, hostels, retail and F&B outlets, among many others. We were also attracted to the various red-brick buildings. They were very nice and magnificent and solely the property of the University. In deed, this place was just like a mini-town by itself and its full of energy, vibe and activities on going.

We walked around the campus and soon we came by the most visited place in the campus. The statue of the sitting "Mr Harvard". Many people came forward to be photographed and touching the "leg" and hopefully their children/grandchildren will be blessed to be as smart. Haha, a myth? Anyway, just to clarify that this person was not Mr Harvard (the founder of the institution) himself. As in those days, the university was unable to find a photo of Mr Harvard himself when erecting a monument in honour of him, it organized a contest to look for the "most good looking" person and selected the winner to have the monument made after him. So this "Mr Harvard" was handsome. This story was shared to us by our guide.

The campus was lovely and serene, with buildings surrounding greenery landscape and with chairs and benches around for students or visitors to sit and rest while enjoying the beauty of the campus. There was a train station in the campus, besides many nice architectural buildings like churches as well.

So we walked around the campus with a feeling of being a "Harvard" student and somehow feel "proud" to be one as the university is world ranked Number 1.

We came by the campus circle where eateries, cafes and retail shops were located and had our breakfast there. People here were orderly and well mannered and polite. Prices here were reasonable and cheaper than elsewhere. Thereafter, we walked around the gift and book stores nearby, grabbing up some books and souvenirs.

Finally, we landed at the Graduate School of Arts and Social Sciences where I caught up with my associate for a while. Visited briefly on the LTs as well and was briefed about the history of the university and the years of transformation. I was then led to the Co-op store, ran by the students on vacation and bought some gift items as well as a form of support.

It was a lovely walk-around trip in Harvard university in Cambridge in Boston. The feeling was so closed to heart, perhaps due to the fact that I am an academic too. Shortly later, when returning to my coach, the place got busier and more pedestrians crowd jostling among buildings, traffic lights and cafes. Well, its the start of another day in campus!

Highly recommend for a visit!

title: A beautiful campus.
text: Try to visit in season rather than when it is closed for the summer, during which time much renovation goes on. This is a testament of great American education and philanthropy combined. A great institution that deserves a visit, allow a day, and have lunch at Harvest whilst you are there.

title: A real life Hogwarts
text: Harvard University is absolutely astounding.  The campus is huge, and the history behind the school is amazing.  If you are a fan of Harry Potter, then you

title: Great piece of academic history
text: Beautiful grounds, a wonderful way to spend a couple of hours exploring and taking in the history of harvard.

title: take a walk through Harvard Yard
text: For a nice walk after the bustle of Harvard Square, take a walk through Harvard Yard, which is open to the public although most buildings are now by code card only.  A real sense of history here, generally food trucks with interesting, inexpensive food on the exterior perimeter.

title: family visit was enjoyable
text: Visited museaum with botanical glass display. Was interesting and beautiful. nice campus with grassy area to relax and have lunch

title: The atmosphere of Harvard is wonderful....
text: I just enjoyed walking the campus, and sitting in the chairs under the trees in Harvard Yard at the center. The disappointing thing is that most libraries and exhibits are out of bounds if you don't have a student ID, even just to take a peek. There was a farmer's market today (every Tuesday) on the square that was fun, with live music and food trucks.

title: great
text: We visited the surrounding areas and it's very beautiful. Lots of tours and individual tourist around.

title: Must do
text: If you are in Cambridge, the Harvard Yard is a must do.  It is a great place to walk around, full of history and fun facts.

title: I was there for a college reunion
text:
I was able to walk from the hotel to Harvard Square on a clear day.
Visited Peabody Museum and the "new" (renovated and expanded) Harvard Art Museum.    There's nothing quite like a Harvard Commencement.  This year Renee Fleming (an honorary degree recipient) sang  and Gov. Duvall Patrick, another honorary degree recipient, spoke in the afternoon to the Harvard Alumni Association.

title: Informative, worthwhile.
text:
We got free tickets to do the Harvard tour when we purchased our Duck Tour tickets.  The tour was really good, definitely worth while to learn about what the different buildings are, the history of the University and get some insider info and perspective as it is the students who take the tour. 
Joe was our tour guide and he did a great job, really friendly, funny and v informative.
The tour only lasts about 1hr and we took the T to get there from Boston.

title: I love Harvard!
text: I had the immense joy of actually spending a semester here and everyday got to see the awesomeness around Harvard. I was shocked to see that so many tourists actually come here, but it was quite heartwarming as there are so many things to see on campus even if you are visiting. My parents loved spending days at the many museums, galleries and libraries and as its close to everything, its the perfect place for a day visit.

title: Campus visit
text: We took our son here in June 2015 for a campus tour and football camp.  The campus is beautiful.  The tour was nice.  We were a little disappointed the tour didn't include visiting the dorms, or allow the prospective students more of an insider's view of the buildings.

title: Harvard reeks of sophistication
text: Harvard is a unique place in the pantheon of American colleges and visit lives up to the expectation.

title: Student Tour interesting
text: We took the free your from a current student and found his perspective interesting.  It would seem the tour would vary based on who conducted it.

title: Great way to spend an hour
text: Went on a tour led by a sophomore called oxanna( sorry if spelt wrong) she was witty, informative and obviously in love with Harvard.  She answered all our questions and their where many considering we where from the uk and had no understanding of us university system.  Great stories from history concerning students and their antics, would loved to have seen a dorm room. Would highly recommend this tour.  Easy to get on the red line subway- please make the effort to go.

title: Prestige
text:
My wife and I caught a direct train ride from Boston to Harvard Square, where we joined a student led tour for $10 per person plus tips.

This university is impressive, as to be expected, as it is world famous.

title: Planned visit.
text: We planned this for sometime whilst we were here, and it did not disappoint, the place was like the grounds of Oxford and Cambridge, England, with its historic architecture and deep history. The day was beautiful and sunny, we sat for sometime on the main lawn near the entrance and took in the feeling of being somewhere where history was made, reading through a list of famous people who at one point walked these paths in their time. We visited the whole place, and I can say it was a marvellous, and Well worth it. We didn't pay for the tour, we just made our own way round, and grabbed info from their website as we went.

title: Cambridge &Harvard
text: This awas a very straightforward trip if you do not object to changing stations on the rapid transfer system. Start at Prudential underground station which is just around the corner from the  Sheraton and was exteremly convenient for most of our travels! For Harvard you change to the red line which takes you right to Harvard square. The tou of the university was interesting and funny with a 4th year student who directs theatre and had already been offered a position with a New York company!

title: Amazing Architecture
text: I loved Harvard. Unfortunately the weather was pretty bad, because there was heavy rain, but we managed to visit all the amazing places. We got a map at the little visitors booth and the nice older Gentleman helped us find everything.

title: Very Historic campus, great atmosphere, geniuses are made here
text: my friends daughter was invited to take summer school here, she is only 16 years old. I helped move her in. First time i visited the campus. this campus is very historic and nice. Everyone was very friendly and proud of their school. they are very organized for their students.  the only down side is outside the campus gates, where there are a lot of homeless and drifters and you feel uneasy at times.  Really was excited to visit the campus.

title: A university like no other
text: I was there in August 2011. By chance, a group of tourists with their guide passed by and i joined it. It was very interesting to know that the sciences center has the shape of a camera. I learned a couple of interesting things about this university like that Matt Damon studied here. Well i didn't change my life but...it's just that he's a famous actor. Other than that, the rest was ok. I didn't stay there long. The students are used to see tourists.

title: Very impressed by the guide and the University
text: I recently went on a student guided tour of Harvard university as part of my Trafalgar tour. It was fantastic. Such impressive grounds made all the more interesting by our impressive Australian guide, Ben! As an Australian it was great to see he was able to attend Harvard for his studies and he was so passionate about the history of Harvard and passing on that knowledge to our group. The grounds were beautiful also. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

title: Interesting even for a native Bostonian
text: Ronia was a great guide, and, although I have visited Harvard on several other occasions, I learned new information.  The tour went at a steady pace and lasted around an hour and was good value.

title: Harvard tour
text:
Great tour with the City pass. Included the Harvard Natural Hystory Museum.  Awsome mineral collection and exhibi of mammals. History of the campus is interesting.  We toured when they had all their classes,reuniion.
Easy to Get to by Subway.

title: Ha-vad
text: Nice campus, cool to just walk through and see this famous school.  Very interesting, not to busy this time of year so that was noce

title: Beautiful campus
text: Duck tour tickets came with free tour of Harvard which are usually about $10. Tour guides waiting when got off redline train. Our guide was very knowledgable of history of the buildings, famous residents & stories of life as a current student. Amazing campus. Such beautiful buildings. Harvard square also contains lots of good shopping, food places & especially good was the Coop bookstore with over 3 floors of great books could spend hours in this store alone.

title: More history here than you might think
text: Yeah, it's old, but it's still just a university, right? There's more history here than you might think, considering how many presidents and famous people have walked these grounds. I highly recommend the student led tour that you can join in Harvard Square.  The most amazing part to me was that the top floor of Massachusetts House is still used as a freshman dorm, where students can be assigned the same dorm rooms used by John Adams and John Hancock.

title: Great University
text: What an impressive campus. Honestly I have imagined the university area to be a bit smaller, so I was pretty impressed when getting handed a map about the area. I would recommend to do a guided tour or just to walk around and check it out. We went there in May, so the final exams where going on, and it was pretty empty around the campus.  So I would recommend to visit the university during the semester and not in the end of it. Impressive architecture and lovely parks.

title: An amazing and interesting walking tour of Harvard University
text:
A great value walking tour of the amazing Harvard Uni with our fantastic, funny, knowledgeable and charismatic tour guide Lelaina, a recent graduate who delighted us with stories and the history of Harvard. What an amazing experience to be able to attend Harvard!
The grounds and buildings were full of history and tradition with Lelaina telling us a few stories about famous past students and the buildings themselves, particularly the amazing library. We also walked around some of the student quarters and finished up at the Harvard shop run by students. We bought some stuff of course!
This tour has a very high rating from us for the importance  of its history and the people who have attended in the past; and for the people who may attend in the future. And for our tour guide who brought it all to life for us with our brief visit.

title: Yet another time!
text: I have visited Harvard multiple times including this latest visit. Parking is a struggle in and around Cambridge so if you find a good spot to park, do so and enjoy a short walk to the University. The university grounds are usually tourist filled and everyone comes here to take a picture with the statue of John Harvard in the center of the square. The old buildings are great to watch and you can visit the library during open hours. Harvard Square in front of the campus has some restaurants and very little shopping. But I would not recommend shopping here. There are much nicer places a little further away.

title: Steeped in history
text: Elegant, historic grounds with imposing buildings and a fabulous sence of tradition. Harvard yard is a wonderful park like area with established trees  and sitting areas

title: Harvard Walking Tour
text: The tour was a great way to spend an hour and learn about the history of Harvard and experience the school.

title: Nice campus for a busy in-city location.
text: There are several DIY tours and a map to locate specific buildings but they look the same most of the time. The public is not allowed to visit the library without a student escort, probably to keep the bums out. Nice bookstore with Harvard logo materials.

title: Pretty surroundings
text: This is a beautiful area to just come and wander around, which is what we did. No tour, just looked around.

title: Great Tour of a Great College
text: We took the tour during the memorial day weekend and were lucky to get the special tour with a college student who was in the military.  Very interesting to hear the military aspect of Harvard and well as other facts.  Beautiful college.  Be sure to call ahead for tour schedule as it is done by students and changes.  The office for tickets is right next door to Au Bon Pain the restaurant so you can get your tickets and have some lunch before taking the tour.

title: Beautiful campus - must see!
text: We weren't sure we were going to go over to Cambridge and tour around the campus, but I'm so glad we did!  It was graduation day so there were additional folks around the campus but not so crowded that you couldn't take a nice stroll around.  It really is a beautiful campus with gorgeous buildings.  There was just something about the flags on the square that made me smile.

title: Expensive Office Space for clever Think Tanks
text: Lost faith in Harvard when I realised that they were selling brand and office space to 'research centres' that have barely any relationship to research active faculty

title: Educational and Information Tour
text:
Great Structures, mind blowing architects. Cannot imagine these were constructed and have been maintained for so many years, yet, the complete faculty and management are able to maintain the name of the university. 
The staff and the familiarization given to the visitor on the educational and information tour was presented gracefully with in depth all round information.

title: Beautiful
text: Harvard is gorgeouse! I literally got goose bumps when I walked onto the campus. Definitely worth the visit don't miss it.

title: Worth it if nearby anyway
text: Certainly a pretty and an historic campus. Worth a walk through if you are in the area and have time. Do MIT on the same trip.

title: Just a neighborly visit
text: I'm always amazed at how grounds and buildings look so seasonally different yet always the same .  I love showing people around there

title: Patch Adams classroom
text: It was fun to attend a lecture in a classroom so often represented in movies. One example is Patch Adams but there are many more. None of my medical school classrooms were like these and it made me feel part of the Harvard scene to spend the hour in the classroom.

title: Harvard
text: Historic institution. I liked the nice grounds, and the very nice meeting took. Reviews must be 100 characters so I am writing this sentence.

title: Great visit to Boston/Cambridge/Harvard
text: Loved it all especially the Hop on Hop off bus and the stop is across the road from the hotel. Very easy access for downtown Boston and Harvard as well as Cambridge. The science museum is a 3 minute walk from our hotel in Cambridge. The Galleria Mall was also across the street and is a two minute walk. Nothing to dislike about this trip.

title: Walk the Yard!
text: Walked through here with the wife, daughter and daughter's fiance.  A nice walk in Downtown Cambridge.  We saw a lot of old buildings and John Harvard's Statue on our walk.  Next time I will spend more time wandering around the campus.

title: Need to see
text: Had to visit Harvard during our visit to Boston because of its academic reputation. Was a bit disappointed by the architecture ( it's no Oxford or Cambridge). It was very busy and much of the grass was roped off which make it less attractive for photography.

title: "Mecca of knowledge"
text:
Learning will always be our best tool to personal growth. 
This inspiring campus can motivate anyone to learn.

title: Visited HARVARD UNIVERSITY GROUND, found it interesting but not thrilling
text:
We visited HARVARD UNIVERSITY in BOSTON just 2 weeks ago, and strolled around the well kept grounds, to get an impression how it would be  to study there.  The grounds are in the middle of town, and I found, that although it is very famous, there is not the peace and calm there, that it would benefit the students.

It is pretty crowded there, with all the people visiting town, and the buildings are for sure well built.  But if they are still suitable for a more modern way of studying is the question. 

I must admit, it is a famous university,
it has lots of reputation,
the students have all the advantages of being hired after they studied there,
but..... I would prefer a different university to do my own studies if I would have to
do it again.

It is just too restrictive, too formal for my liking.  But I am an old geezer, and that might
be the reason why I do not fall into the trap of reputation of some institute.

title: Not much to see from outside
text:
Okay it's a university.
It has a history as you would expect.
Buildings are not all that great and the grounds are okay at best.
There is no real "main" part since there is no official main entrance either, pity really.
If you are close by, then sure visit but don't go too far out of your way ...

title: Commencement Week
text: We were there two days before commencement day. There was a lot of activity on campus and outside campus. A lot of grads were walking around in their cap and gown snapping pictures with their families. A lot of excitement in the air!

title: Harvard Museum
text: Took the kids to the museum at Harvard. It was great, very kid friendly, 2 and 6. Lots to see, birds, bugs, dinos, animals and more!

title: Walk around
text: See the yard, visit the bookstore, have some lunch, go to the art museum. Make a day (or part of one) of it. Then (or before) go and visit MIT.

title: Inspiring and peaceful
text: It was exciting to think that I was walking in the footsteps of so many famous people. It was also tranquil and extremely pleasing to the eye.

title: Wonderful Tour of Harvard
text:
Loved this walking tour of Harvard University led by Eli on May 17th.  He was informative, humorous and full of fun facts.  Eli is so talented, he can walk backwards faster than I can walk forwards!  We covered the main campus - Harvard Yard, Widner Library and several dorms.  He had stories about each of the buildings including why they were built, who lived there and other interesting facts.  

You can't cover the entire campus in a little over an hour, but this gave you some fun facts and the opportunity to ask questions.  We bought our tickets at the news stand near the info desk about a half an hour before the tour.  So, probably no need for reservations.  The price was the same as the on-line price.

Eli also recommended a lunch spot that was just great, Grendel's.  I strongly recommend the portobello reuben.

title: Tour Of The Campus.
text:
Guided walking tour of the campus with Eli. This guy was extremely knowledgeable,he had many informative tidbits of information. He was funny, witty and his dialogue was riddled with puns which kept his,all aged, audience attentive. 

He told us that his concentrator was Human Evolutionary Biology and his secondary was drama! I will definitely be looking for him on Broadway in the not too distant future. 

I highly recommend this tour and if you manage to get Eli it will be a bonus. 

Good luck in your future endeavours Eli

title: Havard like you would expect
text: Very nice campus, but I think it delivers what most people expect. Harvard is a very unique institution and you can spend days going over the history and influence of the university. You can also do simple walk through, which is what I did.

title: Harvard the place of academic gravitas
text: Walking through Harvard is a stroll through what you expect of a respected university, lots of red brick, students studying or lounging, the amazing Natural History Museums.

title: It is Harvard-what is not to like!
text: Leading educational institution in the world.  If your child is fortunate enough to get in, by all means go.  It is a wonderful experience and offers so much to those fortunate enogh to atten.

title: A great university
text: People like to walk around Harvard Yard to soak up the atmosphere. This works best, of course, when the university is in session. In the summer, you might see students who look much too young -- this is not just because you are getting older, but because it is Harvard Summer School, which enrolls many high school students.

title: Nice walk and photo-taking
text:
The University, being an Ivy League, is something one of us wouldn't like to miss. And when you're already in Boston, don't miss this, it's a few minutes drive from the city. 

Strolling around and in the campus premises is a good exercise. Walking past the Harvard Square, you'll see inside the campus John Harvard's statue and the Library. Unless you want and intend to get in this University, I don't think you need to walk all around and see the entire campus. Nevertheless, it is interesting to see and be in its vicinity. Missing university days.

title: Cool to see in a tour
text: We took the tour at the hardvard square for 10$, that was very much fun and interesting. But its a pitty you cannont visit one of the buildings from inside

title: Ivy League,splendour
text: A beautiful campus full of some of Americas Brightest. I was fortunate enough to see some of the engineering labs and the clean lab in particular. The gardens are well maintained and the architecture is stately. I went into the chapel and library. Beautiful buildings with memorials to those from Harvard that had given their lives. I also went into the museum of natural history. An extremely interesting museum and in particular an old fashioned setting for many of the displays which showed the part of the extensive collection used for education over the years. Particularly impressive are the glass flower displays

title: Hahvahd tour given by a senior student of Harvard university.
text: Wonderful, funny and entertaining, would do it again because there's so much to learn about this amazing school!

title: Lovely buildings and grounds! Definitely worth visiting!
text: My cousin convinced me that it was worth the bus ride from Cambridge (Lechmere) over to Harvard Square. Although tired, we went one afternoon when we were through sight seeing for the day. I'm so glad she talked me into it. The buildings are just like you see in the movies and the grounds are immaculate. The students are so lucky to have an environment like this. I was enthralled.

title: Quick trip to see some friends.
text:
We strolled through Harvard Yard for the first time since my daughter graduated. It was bittersweet. Harvard Yard and it's surrounding buildings are very beautifully maintained and just lovely. There was much preparation going on for the upcoming graduating class. 
We hope to return this summer and take more time to enjoy the yard.

title: History and beauty!
text: A great stroll through the area on a snowy March day. Amazing history & great atmosphere. It was an interesting experience overall, definitely worth seeing.

title: What a lovely place to study
text: It was a real treat to visit Harvard Square.  It reminded me of a dozen films and I'm actually envious of the lucky students who get to study in such an amazing place!

title: "When I was at Harvard..."
text:
How many of us have wanted to say, "When I was at Harvard..." Well, for $10 you can! The 90 minute tour of the Harvard campus is a really great way to glean a little about the history of this great institution. 

The tour is conducted by Harvard students and our guide, a sophomore from Vermont, was excellent. She was fully conversant with the history, had an engaging personality and a great sense of humor. 

It was interesting to hear about the 'back stories' of some of the personalities who have made this institution a world leader. It wasn't all 'historic' in that sense; we were introduced to two of the university's modern influential characters: Gates and Zuckerberg. 

The Harvard student led tour is a great experience.  Afterwards, hang around Harvard Square and enjoy the ambience.

title: It was a good overview tour
text: I took the student-led tour. It was informative. I was surprised how poorly the tour guides (this was the official tour for the University) and the people on the tour are treated while on campus. There was one instance of what I took to be a professor openly mocking our tour guide and people in another building telling our tour that we could not stay in their building - it was only for people associated with the University. However, the lore of Harvard managed to over-ride the snobbishness of some of its staff. I then extended my tour by walking over much of the rest of the campus - a fascinating campus to explore.

title: Very impressive
text: Go to the Information Center and thake a guided tour by Harvard students. It starts every hour, if there is a group of min. 10 people. They tell show you the historic part of the campus and tell you much about the history of the Harvard University - it's for free and you get a -15% voucher for the Harvard store :)

title: A Beautiful and Historic Campus
text:
Few universities boast as beautiful and as historic a campus as Harvard. If you want to see one of the oldest universities in the United States, a tour of Harvard is worth your time. The Harvard Yard is both aesthetically pleasing and immaculately maintained; and when you walk through the arches to enter the yard, you quickly realize you are stepping back into history-- in fact, some of the buildings go back several hundred years. 

The campus has a number of excellent museums which are open to the public, and the Harvard Archives are a delight for any historian or researcher who wants to learn more about the many famous people who attended Harvard.  You don't have to be a student to appreciate what the Harvard campus has to offer, from art and natural history exhibits to educational lectures to music festivals; and if you take the tour, you will also see many interesting varieties of architecture.  It is not surprising that so many out-of-town tourists make sure a visit to Harvard is part of their trip to the Boston/Cambridge area. While walking around Harvard Yard or taking the tour is free, some of the museums do have an admission charge, but it is generally very reasonable.  There is limited on-street metered parking available, but a few parking lots are in close proximity.  However, if possible, you are better off going by public transportation, which will give you more freedom to take your time, wander the campus, and enjoy all that Harvard University has to offer.

title: Great place to visit
text:
Was great and enjoyed our visit. Lots of things were going on in the campus. Music festival was great. We also visited the museum which has flowers,fruits, leaves and many more things made of glass which was very impressive and interesting.
   We just went round and saw all the departments,Library, law school. business school.

title: Fun to walk around the campus
text: It is clean, friendly, safe, and has cute stores. There is a lot to see and it is right off of the T.

title: Beautiful Campus In Heart of Cambridge
text: Harvard University is a world famous ivy-league school in the heart of Cambridge. The campus is fabulous and if you have time, take the free campus tour.

title: Great sightseeing!
text: Great trip experience in Boston, especially in Harvard University and around. It's worth to take time enjoy the atmosphere of history and life. Y(^_^)Y

title: Loved the Free tour
text: First time to the area and did not know what to expect.  We did the free student tour and I cannot remember the name of our guide but he was both informative and charming.  Loved his stories and historical facts.  He was very knowledgeable and we thoroughly enjoyed his stories and humour.  Lasted an hour which was long enough and a must do when you come to the area.

title: Excellent tour - a must do if you want to see Harvard!
text: Went on the guided student tour with Francesca, a Harvard student (astro physics), and it was definitely the best guided tour we've ever been to! She was knowledgable, witty, revealed Harvard inside info, mixed historical and architectural input with fun little stories. An absolute must do if you are visiting Harvard - and try to find out when Francesca is doing the tour! :)

title: Skip the tour
text:
Ok, Ok, the tour is free.  You sign in at the tour center across the street from the campus and you're shown, oh, about three buildings and told the usual anecdotes.
But do you learn anything interesting?  Not if you have a tour book or access to the Internet.
We did learn, however, about the tour guide's roommates.  And why she came to Harvard.  And what her major is.  And that Lady Gaga has visited.  Oh, and that George Washington kept some of his troops there during the *civil* war.

title: Interesting Campus
text:
We visited here with a tour group on 4/6/15.

Unless you have a tour guide (which we did) to point out some of the historical buildings and share stories of their significance, there is not much to really see on the Harvard campus.

The history is definitely interesting, but for the average sightseer there is not much to it.

title: Beautiful campus in the heart of Cambridge
text:
My son is college shopping.  We had visited Tufts the day before, and while that campus was lovely, it has nothing on the history and tradition of the Harvard grounds.  Beautiful quads, scattered across a walkable distance, old buildings mixed with new, the great student vibe - you couldn't ask for a better day out.

The only drawback was the hugely rude man at the visitor's center.

title: more full of tourists than students
text: Great place to get a flavor of Harvard.  Sit on a bench and watch the tourists, students and prospective students.

title: Lots of History
text: Tour guide was wonderful - done by actual students.  They know their history of the university here and all the fun gossip too!  Great tour - beautiful buildings. Makes we want to go back to school (almost) !

title: A nice campus
text: We loved strolling trough the campus and seeing the buildings, also the different time periods represented and sculptures add to the inviting feeling

title: Nice walk on one of the world best university
text: Nice walk on one of the world best university. You will pass many building with stories in it. Visit Bronze John Havard statue in Havard yard

title: Harvard University Grounds
text: The university grounds were still covered with snow when we visited but we can imagine how beautiful they will be later in the year.  The old university campus is stunning.  Understandably access to buildings e.g. the amazing  Library are not accessible to visitors.

title: Loved it!
text: You can take a tour of Harvard & Harvard Square but we just walked around by ourselves...not really much open when we went but was so lovely to walk around. The buildings and gardens are so pretty and the atmosphere in the square is buzzing, even when it was freezing cold! Would love to go back in the summer and have more time to explore all the little places!

title: Take the Free Tour!
text: The free hour long student lead tour is a MUST!  Visiting the campus is a treat but learning the historical context and modern uses of the buildings makes the experience far more enjoyable.  The Visitor's Center is across the street from Harvard Yard and the students working there are helpful and friendly.  Our two sons, 8 and 10 years old, were entertained as well!  We could hear them sharing the details of the tour with their grandmother over the phone that evening.  Don't miss out on this opportunity to enjoy Harvard's history!

title: Lovely place to stroll
text: Harvard Yard is the heart of the original college. With free WIFI and Harvard mobile tour you could walk around yourself and take your time. Or you could take the Harvard Student-Led Walking Tour which is informative and friendly.

title: Read Up Before Visiting or Regret It
text: Didn't really see much of this place as it was crowded with tourists on a Sunday in the middle of summer and we were passing through to get to the campus proper. There's so much to this place. Surely for the unprepared like us, we owe this place another visit.

title: Good walking
text: Once you leave the Harvard Square area, it is very pleasant walking amongst the buildings of this old, established University. Much of it is of course not open to the public, but you can admire the atmosphere and architecture.

title: Beautiful
text: A very bad winter, I know, but the snow-laden Harvard Yard was doubly scenic at this time of year. Definitely worth a leisurely amble through.

title: Memorial Hall/Sanders Theater is Handsome but Also Deeply Touching
text:
We have been attending concerts at Sanders for 45 years; it is our favorite intimate concert hall in Boston. Its major negative is the discomfort of the too shallow/ crowded bench seating, (and the [basement level] bathrooms are reached down long steep stairways) but the rich beauty of the interior design, wood panelling and the stained glass windows and carved quotes, along with the warm clear acoustics, easily offset the discomfort. 
What never ceases to move me is in the high vaulted space of the lobby. Memorial Hall was indeed built as a memorial- to all the Harvard boys who died in the Civil War. When you read the marble plaques that line the walls,with their names and the places where they died,  you really do realize the sadness of that War- that was so essential to forming the country that we have become. It always makes me stop and reflect, and appreciate the sacrifice of such young boys. 

Memorial Hall was designed by the very famous Victorian architects, Ware and Van Brunt, and within a block of it are many other famous buildings. The modern School of Architecture and Landscape Design is right across the street, designed by local architect, Graham Gund. Just down the street is the Carpenter Center of Visual Arts, the only American building designed by le Corbusier. And more examples abound throughout the campus.

title: Is this what Ivy League looks like?
text: We took a group of top students to a Harvard invitational event. The representatives of Harvard were not welcoming. As a matter of fact, they were rude. There were no places for our students to sit. It was in the middle of a snowstorm and people were coming in and out of the building covered in snow. With no where to sit, our students had no choice but to sit--in their dress clothes--on the damp floor. There wasn't enough seating, enough food, or enough space for the number of students competing. None of the (dirty, seemingly forgotten) rooms were marked nor set up for our events. This was Harvard's chance to impress and inspire these high school students; instead, the students left wondering what all the hype is about. A very disappointing experience after working so hard to earn this trip.

title: Worth a stop
text: Even in the midst of a record Boston snow storm, the sidewalks were cleared. I do recommend reading up on the history of Harvard before your visit so you can appreciate what you're seeing. My daughter discovered a list of fun facts and enjoyed reciting them back to us while we were there.

title: Best University of US
text: like the buildings and atmosphere of the campus, worth to take a walk and look around the best university.

title: Tranquil and inspiring
text: Think about some of the brilliant minds that have crossed this yard. Fantastic and I am sure will be a long held memory

title: An experience
text: Attending a week long course set in the Harvard Law School I was able to pretend that I was a student in the Paper Chase. exactly how I pictured it.

title: Amazing
text: It really is a stunning place to visit, so big and the buildings are fabulous. Very interesting. You can get walking tours around it but I preferred to wander around at my own pace. An absolute must if visiting Boston

title: It really is the holy grail
text: Do give yourself an extra day to explore campus, the utterly fabulous bookstores and the surrounding city.

title: A nice walk
text: This was an interesting place to walk around, but is spread over a HUGE area.You cant access most libraries etc without being a student there.

title: Arts First
text: Check out Harvard's Arts Festival, usually held the first few days of May.  What an amazing experience!  Harvard students studying music, present dance, vocal, stage and instrumental performances in at least twelve different venues, including Harvard Yard, Memorial Church, and Sanders Theatre.  It's a feast for the senses, and an opportunity to visit historic buildings.  This all takes place in the middle of Harvard Square, the heart of Cambridge, MA.

title: The architecture!
text: Seriously the best part about Harvard was the architecture and feeling nerdy but the architecture for sure. The buildings are beautiful!

title: Historical city campus
text: Easy access by public transportation (parking may be more challenging). Lovely, historical campus that will make you take tons of pictures. Lots of museums, restaurants, shopping in the surrounding area.

title: Harvard Square
text:
I have spent numerous times wanderng around Harvard.  The nbatural history museum is very worthwhile to explore.  Many interesting itmes to investigate.

Be careful walking along the sidewalks, some need repairiing.  If the opportunity allows, go to Sanders Hall, it is most beautiful inside. The walnute panels are in perfect condition, also in the entry hall, there are two stained glass windows.  It is a beautiful building.

title: Amazing 1636 history all around you!!!
text: For me, the fact that this instruction has been around since 1636 gives a since of wonderment on how many scholars had stood in the same I had. It is truly an institution of higher learning. My son is now a junior, and the pride of his accomplishment is unexplainable. Their are plaques and momentos of passed students and their accomplishments that one can only take pride in. I am visiting Boston and Harvard in a week. The snow that has fallen in recent weeks does not deter me one bit. This condition has been endured by others, which has results in their success ultimately. Go to Harvard university with a full day to take everything in, a half day is not enough in my opinion. Learn to use the subway system, and your travels will be less of a strain on your finances. There is history at Harvard and Cambridge enjoy it.

title: Harvard for the museum especially
text: See the new Fogg, Sackler, and Busch-Reisinger museum in the renovated Harvard Art Museum, an ambitious and memorable new project by Renzo Piano.  Amazing German art in the Busch rooms.

title: Living History
text: Harvard Yard is the old center of activity. The paths were determined by where people walked, a brilliant method called "Lines of Desire" — now accepted by landscape designers the world over. Two of the big brick dorms house POWs — redcoats captured further north in the first winter of the war of independence. Many stories. Try to guess which of the people you see are future Masters of the Universe, and which are just wannabes like you and me.

title: Nice
text: Interesting to see. Amazing history, great atmosphere, excellent guide. It was an interesting experience overall, definitely worth seeing.

title: Great!
text: Loved Harvard. Their campuses are sprawling and very grand in places, so we spent a good few hours walking around and people watching. Good grounds, good security and great people watching. Take your camera.

title: Good to finally see
text: Went here today to finally see the great Harvard University and it was a nice campus and school to see and I was glad I finally saw it. But not as grand as I would have imagined.

title: Professional Seminar
text: This was my third professional seminar at the Harvard Graduate School of Education.  It is top of the line in educational experiences!

title: do some shoe rubbing...
text: the harvard yard is a green leafy courtyard which transforms you to another world, serene and away from the hustle bustle just a few steps away... must see for the natural beauty of a college campus. Don't forget to rub John Harvard's shoes for luck (and possible help with the admissions process! )

title: Beautiful Campus
text:
The dining room looks just like out of Harry Potter. A must see. When I was studying there, I made sure to check out the spots that have been the location of movies, particularly where Love Story was filmed.

I was there in 2007 but the drop down menu here won't let me go that back.

title: Somewhere I have always wanted see
text: and I was not let down. It felt magical to be there. plain and simple. The rod iron gates are beautiful and the buildings are beautiful. After a freezing cold walk through the yard we went to a super cute bar in town and had hot spiked apple cider. amazing day. Cambridge is a perfect little town

title: A great university
text: We were in Harvard December 31st. There were some tourists  but everything was closed. We will be back some day.

title: Prestigious !
text: Very pleasant place to visit. We like this place. One of the most prestigious university in the world.

title: Very pleasant walk
text: If you have ever wondered what it would be  like to attend a top notch university then if you are in Cambridge Boston try a sunny walk around the campus .As we only had a short time we strolled around but you can also take guided walks , there are some very fine buildings and the central campus is also green with lots of grass and trees , a very pleasant day .It is easily reached via Underground tube and there are plenty of Cafes and restaurants in the local area with some quite quirky shops .

title: A must if you are in the area
text: This place this worth a visit for the history and prestige if you are already in the area - not a must see if you are considering travelling especially for it. We went for a student guided tour, which I would suggest doing for a good insight. If you miss the times then there are apps and audio guides you can download. One small downside is that you cannot visit the inside of the buildings or see any lectures ongoing (understandable for the disruption this would cause to the students).

title: 2 hours to spend time!
text: Harvard area is one of the most wonderful place to be any time! The restaurant, the cafés, the shops, the churches everything look awesome!

title: Beautiful university.
text: School is beautiful, many spots to take pictures. A lot of restaurants and gift shops to look around.

title: Student Led Tour Well Worthwhile
text: We did a one hour student led tour of Harvard and it was a great way to see the university.  Our tour guide was very friendly and knew a great deal about the history of the University and also gave us an insight as to what it is like to be a student at Harvard.  This is a good way to see the University.

title: Not worth going out of the way
text: I expected a lot more from our nation's first and most decorated university. The town around Harvard is beautiful and fun, but the university grounds are less than inspired. I enjoyed visiting nearby MIT much more. Maybe more exciting and worth while if school is in session, but I have seen dozens of campuses that put Harvard to shame.

title: Harry Potter University
text: Was great to walk the campus and see this honored institution.  The dining hall looks like Hogwarts on the inside.

title: Must visit
text: If you're near Cambridge you just have to visit Harvard University. Actually, there's not so much to see there - the statue of Harvard and some buildings that were important in history but cannot be visited from the inside by tourists. But you should have been there.

title: Don't miss out when you are in Boston
text:
It was not a perfect day to visit as Boston got heavy rain and so cold but the campus made my day. It's an amazing place for me, glad to see the campus, students, church.. So much stories to learn and to tell. I spent a half day, walk from main campus, cross the bridge to Harvard Business School, one of my dream :). 
Don't forget to sign up the free tour, the main counter in front of the MRT station. Also grab some souvenir near by. I like the campus of HBS cos less people and very romantic, along the river.

title: Crimson Commons - Great Food
text: I spent a week attending a program here, stayiong on campus. All of our meals were at Crimson Commons and I must say it may be the best cafeteria food I have ever had. I have 7 meals here and all were very good. I appreciate the effort put into having quality food, especially since we were captive (pre-paid meal) customers which generally leads to lower quality.

title: Stunning University
text: We went there and as we got off the bus we were greeted by a man whose name i think was Dan. He was running the free Harvard tours that afternoon and he was fantastic. Being a past student, he knew everything about the history, architecture and past students of the college. The College itself is fantastic. Great architecture and very interesting to here what famous people had lived in which dorms. A must do when coming to Boston.

title: Historic Walk
text: wonderful place for a stroll. Peaceful, the greenery contrasting so nice with the red bricks of the buildings. The architecture is beautiful. one of the great universities=stunning experience

title: hoorah for Harvard
text: Spent half a day just wandering around the main site. Architecture is varied and splendid. Did a bit of shopping in the Harvard shop since my daughter requested a few authentic Harvard clothing items. One of the highlights of my visit to Boston.

title: Lovely walk
text: It is a great experience to walk though and soak the history, architecture and academic culture of the place. I spent the afternoon and evening just walking around, enjoying the sights and watching the people go by.

title: Wow
text:
Harvard's campus is impressive as its scholastic record. The campus is huge, and filled with some amazing architecture both
new and old.

title: Nice College
text: Great to spend the day strolling through Harvard's Gardens and then poking into Cambridge for some shopping and dining. We visited on our way up the coast and had a nice time

title: Historic and Cinematic
text:
It was a great tour of Harvard by my colleague who teaches there. It's surprising how much I recognised from watching so many American films that have used it as a location.

American history isn't a long affair, but at a place like Harvard you get a sense of it, even on a chilly December day.

Really great experience.

title: Worth a walk through
text: This is an American institution and it's definitely worth a walk through the Yard. Few of the educational buildings are open to the general public, but it's nice to see the architecture and soak up some history (or relive some of your favorites moments from books, memoirs, and movies). With Harvard Square nearby full of shopping and restaurants, this is a good place to come before or after a meal.

title: Probably the best place to see in Harvard - definitely worth a visit
text:
We took the Red Line transit from Boston to Harvard - less than 20 minutes from central Boston.

Harvard Yard is very close to the transit station and was the highlight of my visit to Harvard/Cambridge. Some lovely large old buildings and coloured chairs on the lawns. If you are there in the Fall/Autumn the trees are changing colour and offer some lovely picture opportunities. Obviously a place steeped in history and learning and we just wandered around by ourselves soaking up the atmosphere for half an hour or so.

It is well worth a visit and the best and most memorable part of my morning in Harvard. If you are visiting from Boston then we found a morning or afternoon was enough.

title: Breathtaking campus and excellent free tour!
text:
Visited Harvard on a recent trip to Boston. It was a short "T" trip via the red line, headed towards Alewife. The station name is "Harvard" and it brings you right to the famous Harvard Square. We joined a Student-Led Tour that departed from the Harvard Information Center, in the Smith Campus Center.

It was a walking tour of adult tourists not students. Our student leader was Jimmy. He was very familiar with the campus history, facts and details of the buildings interjected with lots of personal antidotes. Very enjoyable, personable and interesting young man.

We enjoyed the wonderful warm fall day and toured the following: Harvard Yard, Freshman dorms, Tercentenacy Theater, Widener Library, Memorial Hall, a Science centre, the John Harvard Statue and more. We did not enter any of the buildings except for the Memorial Hall. The building are amazing...red brick, some 300 years old. There are mature trees and wonderful roof lines to admire as well as steeples and grassy slopes. The architecture was striking...with a mix of traditional striped roofs and modern glass buildings from the 1070s.

After completing the tour we ambled around the campus to look at the Harvard Lampoon building. A quirky building with a smiling mouth and eyes. We recommend wandering the campus and enjoying all the free statues and the heritage buildings with their dormer windows. Breathtakingly Beautiful!

If you have time and the weather is fair, I recommend a short walk along the Charles River for a look at the buildings and bridges

Being tourists, we also stopped into the Coop store for some retail therapy. Lots of Harvard souvenirs to be purchased!

The campus is well worth an afternoon of touring! Apparently there are 100 plus iron gates...we only saw a few, maybe next time!

title: Enjoyed our tour with a non-quintessential student at Harvard
text: We did the formal information session followed by the tour of Harvard because my son is considering attending there.  The student who guided us was quite delightful and did not fit my image of a typical Harvard student at all.  I was particularly impressed with the way she talked about the dorm living there and how students are matched with roommates.  I could almost picture the "sorting hat" from Harry Potter, calling out the names of the students and which house they would be placed in for that year.

title: Informational and Entertaining
text: If you have the time, be sure to take the Harvard campus tour.  Our tour leader, "Ollie", was fantastic.  The tour included both the Old and New Harvard Yard as well as the Memorial Chapel.

title: Lovely
text: I would highly recommend a trip out to Harvard. It was so beautiful and just a world apart from the downtown city. Its incredible to see this place for real after seeing it in so many movies! Go have a coffee and a wander enjoy the buzz

title: Wow! Who knew there was a 'John Harvard''?!
text: We came to the Harvard-Yale football game and made a point to walk Harvard Yard during pre-game festivities. I knew Harvard was older (1633) than our country, but we're never told about John Harvard.  Fortunately his statue draws a crowd in the Yard and we came across it.  Glad to know more about the founding father of this fine academic institution!

title: Helpful people
text: WE went to an athletic event --the security people were helpful and very polite --speaks well for Harvard

title: Spectacular Experience
text: Was at Harvard for a meeting and got a guided tour of Harvard University. Was fascinating to see the famous University and learn more about its history and what makes it unique. Was able to rub the famous shoe for good luck at the statue although I was pleasantly surprised to learn that the statue is actually not for Harvard and that it was not Harvard who founded this famous University. Spectacular place to be.

title: Be sure to take a tour
text: We had a tour by a member of the Crimson Key Society. Excellent tour guides!! Even if you have done an admissions office tour, this will be different. Loved it!

title: Awe inspiring !
text: Endless amazing buildings, thousands of students, huge spaces, gardens, all help to create the feeling that you are in the midst of an academic powerhouse. Worth visiting Harvard Yard and the buildings if you can gain access. The libraries, in particular, are especially impressive.

title: Autumn at Harvard
text: It is amazing walking through Harvard's yard and all the buildings. Brownstone building at the Yard are the classic view of Harvard, but all the others outside yard constructions are also spectacular. Beautiful at autumn.

title: Some really interesting sites
text: If you get a chance to go to Cambridge (small city (town?)) across the river from Boston, stroll the downtown area and tour Harvard. Harvard has many interesting buildings and sites (such as a stained glass hall devoted to victims of wars) and a tour will surely keep your interest. After your tour, stroll the charming shops of Harvard Square.

title: I Recommend Self-Guided Harvard Yard Tour on Mobile App
text:
We went to Harvard on a drizzling day and without knowing better, joined the free (you pay tips) student-run tour departing from the student center. After 10 minutes we had to leave the tour - while it's pretty interesting to hear the world-leading uni's story from an actual Harvard student, her voice was totally overwhelmed by the rain and I could hardly hear her in a 30-strong crowd. 

I ended up downloading the free Harvard Yard tour app on my iPhone and did my own exploration. The app depends on Internet access to function but throughout the Harvard Yard you should be able to access the free (albeit slow) uni guest wifi access. The app does a pretty good job at providing historical and sometimes humorous perspective on the famous university. 

Overall I enjoyed the visit to the university - but I am a nerd and being in Harvard was half the enjoyment itself. If "one of the world's best universities" does not interest you on itself, you may not find the Harvard Yard interesting. Most buildings are off limit so all you could see is really just the facade of the buildings, and this may not be all that interesting if you belong to the "sightseeing tourist" category.

title: That is the teaching and learning edifice, I've heard most about, so far !
text:
And now as the final point and one of the most precious moments, that happened to us during our short visit to Boston, I must mention the glorious site of the Harvard University in Cambridge.
This beautiful town Cambridge across the River Charles, off the Boston, counts for its own as the city ,though one could assume that it is one extension of the main city of the Massachusetts.
Here, whole campus with grounds ,yards, gorgeous buildings of different fields of the science, the monuments of the most deserved men throughout the history of the Harvard are at the reach of us, the visitors, the tourists. Like for instance, the sitting statue of the first  Harvard benefactor, John Harvard ,who was also the alumnus of the University of Cambridge. After his decease ,the name of Harvard College was honored to the existant institution of Cambridge University.
That was in the 1636, the year of Harvard University establishment.
We enjoyed at the times to walk on these green yards and around the buildings, perceiving this splendid architecture of the edifices, acknowledging the great University history and also getting acquainted with the nowadays life of that grand Campus.
We saw within these grounds, the greatest library in the world, the Widener Library.
Some sculptures of the renown sculptors as Henry Moore adorn the Harvard University gardens.
That is outstanding place to be seen for all the times.

title: Living History Since 1636
text: Even if you’re not a student here, the Yard speaks its history to you as you walk around.  Take a tour, or not, it doesn’t matter.  Sit on one of the terrific, colorful metal chairs everywhere and drink in the uninterrupted centuries passed under these same trees by young people going back so far that George Washington kicked out a dorm full of them in order to quarter his troops during the Revolutionary War.  It’s amazing, really, and it’s all free.

title: Tour of  Harvard.
text: This was an exciting & enjoyable  tour of the Famous Harvard University given by a  Harvard student  guide.  ($10) The magnificent buildings, grand Harvard history, beautiful grounds, & the life at Harvard University. Delightful Tour!

title: There were no caars  in the Haarvard  Yaard
text: There were students, tourist and lots to see. Our tour group was small and the guide was had lived in the area all her life. She had many stories about former Presidents and important people who attended Harvard. Admission was free. If you don't factor in the price of the cruise. Boston is a must see, we'll be going back.

title: Harvard Yard and Square
text: Well-worth a visit: buzzy and safe.  Many of the college buildings are accessible and the grounds pleasant.  Frequent exhibitions in some buildings.  Also a good place to eat.  Almost a attractive as Cambridge, Cambs!

title: A wealth of history
text: A great place to just walk around the gardens, although the university itself is off limits to the general public it is still a fascinating place to visit.

title: Great place to be in the Summer and fall and good pics in winter and spring
text: The yard is alive with activities, tourists and nature during all seasons. In the summer and fall lots of people and activities for family fun and  nice for romantic walks; in the winter and spring you get great pictures of nature. And if you are from Boston you can get excited about being inside Harvard yard with its rich history and the statue of John Harvard...

title: Harvard is lovely but the area around is a mess
text: We were interested to see Harvard and it was very interesting and lovely to see. We wondered for about an hour. Worth a look however I thought the area around was a mess and let's the whole place down.

title: History, prestige and fascinating stories!
text: Take a tour with the Harvard student - led group (free!) by registering in the Harvard information center in Harvard Square. The groups are large and you might have to ask the student to speak louder but the (approximately) hour long tour is great! It includes history, personal anecdotes and all questions are answered intelligently, of course!

title: Harvard Yard Is Worth A Visit
text:
While Harvard sprawls into the area surrounding 
Harvard Square, and many of the buildings are non-remarkable, the same cannot be said of Harvard Yard, which is pretty and has a palpable sense of history. It is a very short walk from the Harvard Square Subway Station.

title: Informative and Entertaining
text: The tour is lead by students who make it informative as well as very entertaining. I thoroughly enjoyed my $10 tour, which was a bargain considering it is at least an hour long. I expressed my appreciation by purchasing lots of things in the official student shop at the end of the tour.

title: Lovely afternoon walk
text: We enjoyed strolling around the area. Sat on the lawned area near John Harvard statue and was able to log on the free Harvard wifi. There were lots of chairs scattered about for anyone to use. A great idea.

title: Nice to walk around
text: Didn't have enough time to go on one of the guided tours so have a little walk around by myself. The buildings are gorgeous. Enjoyed my brief visit.

title: Alumna memories
text: It was all I remember, but better (flowers, nicer weather).  Loved seeing my old stomping grounds and Memorial Church is more lovely than I remembered

title: University
text: University like many others. I don't have any connections to Harvard and never even wanted to study there so it was rather boring for me.

title: University
text: Although one of the best, it's still just a university and people study there. So unless you have some kind of special connections to this place, nothing really special.

title: Attended a seminar there
text: Beautiful location.  Free student tours. Highly recommend the tour to get the real story of the history, the statues, and the life of a Harvard student.

title: America's most famous campus
text: Just like every picture or film made at this place lovely to walk around remembering all the times I had read about this place in a book or seen a film with this at the heart of a character's life

title: Great Area. Lively. Football Game Fun
text:
What an awesome area. Very lively and fun. Lot to see.  Took in a  Harvard football game which was actually pretty good.  They're on a roll so the game was fun to watch. 

The historic stadium looks as such and bring a cushion to sit on. The entire Harvard Stadium is one big block on concrete.  It's a great place to watch a football game. Easy in and out.  Site lines great  and as a season ticket holder for the NY football Giants I had a better experience here than I ever do in that billion dollar dump of a football stadium in the swamp called Metlife Stadium.

title: Student Watching/Nationalities Galore
text: Harvard Yard area is a feel for the international.  So many people from all over the world. The area is so busy and bustling. Watch, listen, absorb. You are in a great place of academia!

title: Great University Experience
text: With family members having attended and also taught at Harvard, a return to the Cambridge area was fabulous. Take the time to look at statues, sit in the commons, check out the architecture of the buildings and just people watch.  Most fun!

title: Went to bookstore
text: We went to the co op bookstore and looked at all the Harvard books and items. Then we walked to Harvard yard and looked at the John Harvard statute, saw also a library, many buildings and a pretty church. The gates to Harvard were pretty,.  It was a nice day and had lots of interesting things to see.

title: Great for a wander
text: We took the Metro Red Line out to Cambridge and enjoyed a pleasant stroll through the university grounds. Having been to Cambridge, England earlier in the year it made for an interesting comparison. We chose not to join a tour group and having obtained a free map from a nearby student in Harvard Square we had a pleasant amble.

title: Ivy League
text:
So glad we went here. There are free tours given by students and although our paper guide said they would not be running at the time we arrived about 3 pm, we latched onto a tour which had just started. A really fascinating place, the students were back and at work or play. Our guide was very informative and answered lots of questions. She had some great anecdotes about the place and it made us both wish we could relive our university years at Harvard, even hough we are both over 60.
Well worth a visit.

title: Very interesting - but not free!
text:
Firstly, Francesca, our tour guide was great.  She is a sophomore studying Astro-physics and a lovely, vibrant young lady.  Her style was efficient and humourous and just what you would expect from a tour guide.

We were under the impression that the tour was free but was suprised to learn that there was a cost of $10pp - what the?  We thought this was a bit pricey for a tour that lasted 40mins and  just toured the grounds - it didn't go into any buildings.  That being said, the tour was interesting and the grounds beautiful.

title: Harvard is a Great Place to Visit
text: Harvard University is a great place to visit. Begin in Harvard Square (which is very interesting in itself) and go right through the gate into Harvard Yard. Check out the buildings, students and scene as you walk around and take a selfie at John Harvard's statue. Continue your walk though the far side gate onto Quincy Street and turn left. The Harvard Art Museum is on this street. Cross Broadway and continue on Quincy Street, the large church looking structure on the left is Sanders Theater. Turn right onto Kirkland and left onto Divinity and wander around (or go into) the museums of Archaeology, Natural History & Zoology. Meander over to Oxford Street and back to Harvard Yard or Harvard Square.

title: A beautiful campus seen through eyes of a student guide!
text:
One of our son's friends, gave us a personal tour of "his school", and we had such a lovely afternoon.  It is a beautiful campus, with the red brick buildings, beautiful old trees, and many walking pathways to discover between the buildings.  There are many eateries, shops, and services available to student, professor, and tourist around the perimeter of the campus.

Walking over the bridge and watch the rowers go by is a great way to spend a few minutes and soak in the view of the school.  It is a beautiful place of learning.

title: Would have enjoyed it more with a guide
text: Had some time to kill in Boston and decided to visit Harvard.  Took the T as it is the best way to get around the Boston area.  Very nice campus with some beautiful buildings.  I bet us tourists get on the students' nerves!

title: Breath in the significance!
text: One of the most pre-eminent Universities in the World, not just the USA. In a nice area, and well maintained (as you would expect). Take a tour with one of the students, and listen to all the stories - historical and of the achievements of the Alumni. You can't help but be impressed.

title: A Truly American Classic
text: While in town, this is a must see outdoor amenity of Cambridge.  Great for people watching.  Be certain to criss-cross the yard along one of its diagonals and suck in the experience that too many students take for granted.

title: Always a Fun Place to Visit
text: The heart of American higher education is always fascinating to visit.  Awesome resources that only a school with a huge endowment can afford.

title: Great with a good guide!
text: Visited with Daniel Berger-Jones, a local history guide, as our guide.  What a contribution he made to our understanding of the place.  It has a fascinating history but little is apparent to the casual visitor, but with a guide it comes to life!

title: Harvard University - Interesting to visit, great for pictures, not so much "to do"
text:
Easy to get to, we decided to visit Harvard with some time to kill in Boston. It was a great diversion, as it is a beautiful campus with some very nice sights. There are lots of places to get some nice photos, and the area around the campus is a typical college-type atmosphere.

We did not take a formal tour, instead opting for just walking around campus. We hit the area right outside the "T", and started walking. The buildings are beautiful, the campus well taken care of, and the students seem quite pleasant - given there are tourists plowing around.

There are tons of restaurants and other shopping conveniences around the campus, so take your time and enjoy the ambiance.

title: a great place to tour
text:
If you could thru osmosis gain knowledge, my brain would explode.
Take lots of pictures, take your time.

title: It's Harvard!
text: What to say?? The grounds are absolutely gorgeous! Loved spending the day here and walking through the whole campus.....visiting the bookstore....entering a few buildings.....Harvard square...meeting students...the whole experience was great! (And yes I bought Harvard jogging pants!)

title: Soaked in the Smartness
text: I had a great time touring around the campus. I started with the free campus tour and them walked around on my own. A student provided the tour. And it was great to get some insight on student life on campus.

title: Beautiful campus
text: Easy trip on the "T" and when you go up the steps, you are at the gates of the campus. Get a campus map and start walking. Lots of people were doing a student led tour but we did our own thing. You can go in the basement of the Science Research Bldg. To find a restroom.  We also walked down towards the river and caught a glimpse of the rowing team. Then we toured Harvard Square and had ice cream at J. P. Licks.  Wear comfortable shoes.

title: Excellent Attraction
text: This tour give you a fascinating look at life at Harvard University.  Tour guide and Harvard student Alexis possesses  an extraordinarily dynamic personality that constantly held our attention.   Learn about the many luminaries that resided in their dorms right  here before going on to great fame and fortune by changing the world! Learn about the Harvard primal scream and little known Harvard University stories and traditions. Definitely worth it!!!!   We purchased our tickets at the newsstand in Harvard Square  where the tour begins.

title: gorgeous campus, wonderful museum
text: We had only about 5 hours to explore the Peabody museum, and we could have spent a couple of days. The exhibit of hand-made glass flowers was like nothing anywhere else in the world, and the rocks and minerals exhibit was gorgeous.

title: great tour
text: Lovely way to see the campus and hear a little bit about the history of Harvard. It's a great idea to have students run the tour. The random anecdotes were enlightening. It's not easy to simultaneously please parents who are college shopping with their teenagers and tourists who just want to be entertained. I think our tour guide did a great job!

title: Interesting Walk for an Hour
text: It's a nice walk between the old campus buildings, but I wouldn't go much out of my way to see it. The surrounding town has a good range of eateries, some at student prices.

title: Best in class
text:
Harvard University and it's environs represents the pinnacle of meritocracy in education. It's unparalleled reputation and literal "Town & Gown" interaction creates an ethereal spiritualization of freedom of thought that both the ancient Greeks as well as our Founding Fathers imagined. As an alumnus, every time that I return to campus, I take away an endearing desire to utilize the opportunities that the Harvard relationship provides me and to be a better citizen to society as its result.
I love to share my experiences (literally) with friends, which I did last week. By the texts I received afterwards, I think that I succeeded!

title: Hallowed Turf
text: We only visited Harvard Square but the ambience was wonderful.  it was 'freshers' week and the buzz in the air was palpable. The buildings were lovely and it had a real 'Ox/Bridge feel!

title: Fun to Walk Around, but most buildings are closed to public
text: We enjoyed the stroll around Harvard Yard and seeing some of the classical architecture.  Most of the buildings have signs that the general public are not allowed--not surprising.  We had a beautiful day to walk the campus--very lively.  The adjacent village is much more interesting.

title: Good tour
text: Harvard Yard has free wifi, and an app to download to take a self guided tour. We really enjoyed this, as our kids would not have put up with listening to a paid tour guide in a group. Tha app called "Harvard Tour" probably has most of the same info anyway.

title: Harvard is an amazing place to visit
text: The people are gracious, the location is filled with so much beauty and history, and the vibe is Harvard.  I smile and I light up whenever I have the opportunity to speak about my time spent at Harvard.

title: Great Place for a Walk
text: We were fortunate to have good weather for a nice stroll around the campus.  Well worth the visit if you know any Harvard history.

title: If you only visit one university ...
text: Easily accessible by train, this part of Boston (Cambridge) is worth a visit. This is the US equivalent of Oxford or Cambridge - communities which have developed around a university.
