It is possible to just go for a wander, win the help of a map, or to join a tour guided by a Harvard student. These are promoted at the station exit. Look out for the statue of the three lies - a  fascinating example of not letting the truth get in the way of a good story. The range of authentic Harvard-branded goods on sale in the Coop is massive, if this is what you want. There are lots of eating options in the area as well. This is a great way to occupy half a day.

title: Famous Harvard University
text: We took a student lead tour of this historic university, which was free. You can grab your free tickets (for a specific timed tour) from Harvard Information Centre across the gates into Harvard on Massachusetts Avenue. The girl we had, had just  graduated from Harvard and this was her last tour. She did a great job of providing us with the history of Harvard. Explained what the buildings were used for, what life was like at this university. It made the tour very informative and personal for us. The campus itself was very beautiful, the architecture of the buildings was just stunning. And the tree lined grounds making it a wonderful place to study or just relax after class. We had a great time visiting and the surrounding area is also very nice to visit. There's plenty of cafés around to enjoy a coffee afterwards.

title: Worth it
text: Drove up on the long weekend from our stay in Beacon hill just so we could say we did. You can feel the history as you walk around. Beautiful setting and buildings. Book store was a nice break with the kids. If you have an hour of so it is a neat thing to do.....surrounding neighborhood is amazing and I am sure if you have time a few of the local restaurants and watering holes would be fun to visit.

title: Harvard University
text: It is a beautiful campus during the summer, but because of the hype around it I find I built up my expectations too much and was therefore a little disappointed. I have seen other american university campuses that are much more beautiful and interesting.

title: Beautiful buildings!
text: Its really interesting to visit the Yard here. It was the day they were welcoming first year students so it was really fun to see that. I used the Harvard Tour app, which was helpful but I wished it had audio for everything. The sun makes it hard to read, and I wanted to look at more things. Really interesting history.

title: beautiful school
text: Took a prospective student tour. School is beautiful...some of students are snobs.Loved the history and the way the school is set up. Disliked attitude of students at info session. Felt like was being talked down to.

title: Students Everywhere On "Moving In" Weekend
text:
A really lovely, leafy, place with a collection of superb buildings.
Take some time to stop and stare at the world's best (ranked no.1 in 2013/14) university. See John Harvards' statue and remember that the £500 bequest from this Southwark, London, publican's son is now worth $35Bn!

title: Harvard campus tour
text: We came to Boston for a dedication in memory of my best friend in the women's soccer team locker room. We watched a soccer game on the main field. Then walked around the campus. Very pretty and well maintained. Harvard square has fun shops and cafés. It's Harvard  so one would not expect anything less!

title: Busy Yard
text: Chairs were all over as they were in preparation for the school opening. I like the feeling of being in the yard  though it is quite small.

title: Classic and Awesome
text: My first time in Harvard. The feeling is marvelous. I feel like a genius. The campus was on the preparation mode for the freshmen.

title: Had the Student Tour
text: Quite a few of us on the tour but our guide - a third year student I think, was professional and gave us the basic history of Harvard in the appropriate manner. It was all smaller than I thought.

title: This is the Ivy League?
text: My friend and I were both highly disappointed by the Harvard Campus. Perhaps it's because of the way Hollywood makes it look in movies like Legally Blonde, but the old historical part of campus (Harvard Yard) is quite small. It's a pleasant space, no doubt. Chairs scattered across the lawn shaded by tall trees make for a nice place to stop and rest. However, the rest of campus is a vast expanse of nondescript brick buildings. Even the few free museums we went into failed to impress. The Semitic Museum's collection seemed to comprise solely replicas of famous artifacts, although it did have a lot of information on Cyprus, which I suppose impressed us. Boston if full of historical buildings and shady green spaces to wander around. Harvard didn't stand out from any of the others, and they don't require a long metro ride.

title: Pleasant stroll
text: One can appreciate why Harvard is such a great place to study. And, it is pleasant to wander around.

title: Inspiration for Youth of All Ages
text:
We took our kids for a tour of the campus and I think they enjoyed the tour, but getting an honest opinion about a site seeing adventure is like asking if they washed their hands before dinner.
 
Get used to the tour guides calling the it Hah-vard.  Although we weren't able to tour any of the buildings from the inside, viewing the historic architecture from the outside was a treat and I can only imagine the feeling of gratification of attending class there.  

The tour is well worth the donation and the guide was friendly and very informative.  I would definitely recommend the tour for children and adults of all ages.

title: It's Harvard!
text: What a gorgeous campus!  The architecture, the history...what can you say?  I made it a point to visit here on a vacation to Boston, and it didn't disappoint!  I may be in trouble, though...after seeing the campus, my daughter now wants to attend college there.  Heck, I want to go back and attend college here ;-)  It's definitely worth a stop if you're in the area.

title: Worth it for the architecture
text: We were lucky enough to hear an orientation being given so got a little extra history lesson, but if you have even a little bit of time, it's worth going here just for the architecture of the buildings alone.  The gardens are also very pretty.  In fact, the whole campus is very nice and peaceful (we were there early in the morning).  I must admit I wouldn't think walking around a college campus would make for a good attraction, but I found myself glad I did this one.

title: Not so old
text: Pleasant enough but cannot be compared with the beauty of Cambridge University in the UK. The nearby square is very commercial and embarrassingly lacking in rest rooms!

title: Bow to the temple of learning
text: The best time to visit Harvard University, Cambridge is towards the last week of May when a variety of Commencement functions are held at all the Schools. Weather-wise it is very welcoming, neither cold nor hot, of course, there might be occasional drizzles. Fresh intelligent faces are in all smiles because the exams are over and now it is party time. Some are perhaps little sad because the time has come to bid adieu to this wonderful place and their pals, join the real world and contribute to the welfare of mankind. It is a common sight to find youngsters with their parents and siblings who have come from long distances just to be with the graduating wonder in this joyous occasion. They proudly sport caps, t-shirts, jackets etc with logo of Harvard Dad/Mom/ Brother et al. The shopkeepers first congratulate them before doing the business. Service staff in restaurants, many of whom are students themselves, welcome these guests with words which come from their deep within. Cabbies entertain with all kinds of questions. Even the Police, who usually maintain a stony countenance, are a smiling lot. Joy is all-pervasive; it is beyond description. You have to be there to get a real feel of it.

title: HARVARD
text: What else do we need to say about this place it is the BEST and most phenomenal institution of higher learning in the United States and probably the world!! Beautiful gardens and walk spaces. I spent a week learning from the best in my field.

title: Beautiful, great people watching
text: This is the perfect spot to take a break and people-watch,  I was there in the summer and they had tons of lawn chairs for you to arrange to your liking.  Lots of interesting people passing through.  Lovely surroundings.  Food trucks close by for lunch or a snack.

title: Love this place
text: We love the collection of French Fermob chairs on the Yard. It feels like we are home (we are living in Paris) and it makes the yard a different place every time we visit as the colorful display of chairs and benches is changing every day.

title: Dramatic and impressive
text:
We stepped out of the subway and were then in the University grounds.  Lots of red brick, lots of large buildings, a dramatic library and lots of student-y atmosphere.  

We didn't feel the need to do a tour, we saw enough just walking around, and got a good sense of things. There is money here.

It's not possible to do a drive through, and parking in Harvard looked difficult, so we felt we did the right thing to go on the subway.

Lots of good touristy things to do nearby, great place to see with much significance.  All this and MIT too!

title: Old architecture
text: Amazing walk through time. Very old well maintained buildings. Nice to see that old institutions are still in for the younger generation.

title: A very nice choice for a half day visit
text: Harvard University is located in the Cambridge area of Boston and is very easily accessible with the underground. We spend there a little more than a half day and it definately worthed it. The campus is green and well maintained and there's always people walking around. There are several historical buildings that you can visit and also a handful of nice museums. We visited the museum of natural history which was very interesting and holds an outstanding collection of flowers made of glass. We also had the chance to follow a free guided tour of the university held by a student which was very nice and informative.

title: Very nice for a walk and maybe the museum ...
text:
The architecture itself was amazing ... the ambiance and weather permitted us to take a very nice stroll ... I heard the Natural History Museum is nice but could not go on this trip.

Worth it just because you get to see this legendary landmark in world education!

title: Great for the Gardener and the Cook!
text: I loved the illustrations and displays of the edible flora from cocoa beans to vanilla trees along with mollusks and other marine delicacies.  Also loved the glass flowers!

title: Interesting
text: Harvard university is a must see if you come to the Boston area. They have free tours guided by Harvard students that range from one to two hours. A good opportunity to learn a little bit of history.

title: So open and grand
text: With a daughter who is interested in studying in USA we decided to have a quick visit while in Boston. Grand style but so open - lots of people just wandering around - chairs every where. Still quiet and serene.

title: Nice Experience!!!
text:
It was good to visit Harvard Yard on a fine Sunday afternoon. I enjoyed sitting there for a while and enjoying weather.  
I agreed with couple of other reviews like place is too crowded with visitors, but I enjoyed.
It would be great if you take a Harvard walking tour or download audio tours/mobile tours from site. You will enjoy listening to facts.

title: Not really what I was expecting
text: To be fair, when we decided to go to Harvard, we didn't allow ourselves enough time to get out of the car and walk the grounds properly, not did we do a proper tour, so that is definitely skewing my review. We decided to drive around the grounds to see the buildings and try and get a feel for the campus. Well, the campus is huge and with all of the construction going on it was difficult to do a proper "drive-thru." The buildings we did see were old and impressive, but not really the WOW factor I was expecting. Wish we had given ourselves more time to see what we were maybe missing.

title: Beautiful campus!
text: We decided to take our pre-teens to see Harvard. It definitely did not disappoint!  It's a beautiful campus with landscaping and historic brick buildings.  There is also a great campus store for apparel and some shops.  Just really a great area.

title: Awesome campus and friendly staff
text: Harvard's campus is a great place to walk around. A lot of history here. Plenty of trees and shade to walk around in and enjoy the grounds. Shops and restaurants of Harvard Square are right outside the gate. Staff is very friendly. Met a very friendly security guard originally from Pakistan (sorry, don't remember his name), who was very helpful and went out of his way to provide directions. (Thank you!)

title: Take the student guided tour; informative, interesting and fun.
text: We had been advised that student tours of the campus were free but apparently this is only the case from September and not during the summer vacation.  In any event we purchased our tickets, $10, at Out of Town News kiosk just a short walk from the metro station, and were soon off on a guided tour of the campus with Eli, a delightful and entertaining student going into his junior year.  The tour was just over an hour long but it was Eli that made it interesting and informative; he focussed on the history of Harvard - including the buildings, architecture and statues - Harvard traditions and some of the famous people who have attended Harvard.  He was a great story teller and wove in his personal experience of this great University.  He was also very patient and was very happy to answer a range of questions including one or two from some pretty precocious little kids! Highly recommend doing the tour and hope you have as good a guide as Eli!

title: Pretty nice
text: This was good too.. it's more like a luxury hotel. Good fun to walk around and see the buildings.MIT is a better bet though.

title: Now I can say I "went to" Harvard (last weekend)...
text: Harvard is probably my favorite area in Boston, lots of interesting architectures, not your typical college town (probably more of a fancy college town since I don't believe many of those stores will survive in a poor college town).  We also joined the tour, it was funny and enjoyable. The museum of natural histroy has a lot to see.  We had lunch with food prepared by food truck "Bon Me" on campus. The wheelchair accessibility is slightly better than the rest of Boston.

title: Free Harvard Tour
text: Free tours are offered by students (tip afterward if guide did a good job). Meet in the information store which is across the street in the large building, next door to the student clothing store. The tour does provide some interesting historical  information about Harvard and also some of those traditional tales stated over the years.  The tour is slanted more for families who have students that will be attending Harvard and although our son-in-law is attending there, he is a Masters student and obviously independent. Therefore, when conversation about housing and finance began, we had to be patient in order to continue on with the tour.

title: Worth a walk to soak up history and boost the IQ.
text: The older part of Harvard Yard reeks history, tradition and has done a great deal to shape US and world history by serving as a place of learning for generations of leaders.  Hard not to feel the historic aspect as you stroll around and through the gates.  Cambridge is well worth a visit.  Visiting Harvard and MIT is a great thing to do with young teens to help motivate them to be aspirational in their academic and life goals.

title: Worth a visit if you have time
text: Glad to have been and maybe we should have taken a tour to learn more but on the surface a beautiful collection of old buildings housing a wonderful university with a statue of the benefactor out front.  But that was all...

title: INTERESTING
text: Coming from the UK we were very interested to visit Harvard.  As we walked around the yard we saw various actors dressed in period costumes.  At one point, we listened to a talk about the history and statue of John Harvard.  It was lovely to see, what to us could only be seen in films, come to life.

title: So?
text: Interesting. No, not the Harvard Yard. But some people who give a good rating to this place on Tripadvisor. They left a comment like, "I finally made it!" Psshh. Yes this place is historical and can be seen as "amazing," but really - reality is..Harvard Yard is so crowded by tourists,visitors, and students by day. Students don't mind throwing dirty looks to random passengers often times, Camera flashes everywhere, limited footpaths, and it is a very very small yard overall. Not impressed.

title: Harvard grounds
text: Just great to soak up this amazing atmosphere.  Better to have a guide but you can walk the grounds yourself. Check out the science area and the first computer

title: A great way to spend the day.
text: We took the Hahvahd tour that was a walking tour and our student tour leader was Jason, a bright and entertaining young man.  Many things were off limits to the public but a very nice look at this beautiful campus and Cambridge area.  We enjoyed it so much, after a wonderful lunch at Sandrine's, went back to sit at the campus and enjoy the beautiful weather and atmosphere, very nice day.

title: Beautiful
text: Beautiful campus. You can download a free app to take a tour. Its quite big and you can go and have a nice picnic. The architecture is amazing and has several different buildings.

title: Splendid Colonial Buildings & Peaceful Gardens
text: Step back in time and enjoy walking through the tree-lined quadrangle surrounded by handsome period buildings. The noise levels from the city outside subside and you can sit and enjoy the architecture and beauty of the university.

title: Must Visit
text: Some parts fo the campus are under reno at the moment - suggest an evening visit when crowds are low

title: Walk through the yard
text: A green oasis in the middle of Harvard Square.  Be sure to walk through the yard.  Lots of activity and chairs where you can rest for a moment.

title: Great place to walk....
text: And just take in how many notable people have walked these same steps.  Seaver hall has a very cool whispering brick archway where you can hear what people whisper from the other side of the arch.  I think it was Seaver.  I know it started w an S.  Beautiful architecture.

title: I have to agree with the "average" reviewers
text: If you haven't seen it, then you have to visit. Just be aware that just looking at the buildings isn't that great. It's really not that picturesque a school. Buildings are very old, and guess what, they look very old. Take a tour to get some insight, or visit the museums, etc. Lots of tourists wandering through, so lots of unfriendly people. Probably ticks off the students too, who seem to be typically uncaring to others, drifting through their millennial world. Surrounding area, Harvard Square, busily annoying.

title: Feel smarter just to be here
text: One of the best university in the world. Always want to check it out. Old and full of historical buildings. Make you feel smarter even just to be there.

title: Very interesting and worth the time
text: Our tour guide Laura did a great job.  As a student attending the university she was able to give a first hand experience of the school. Although the tours are free of charge they only permit 35 people per tour.  We got there ~ 0950 and the 1000 tour was full.  You can get tickets an hour before the next tour.  So we waited around till 1000 and got the tickets for the 1100 tour, and then went walking around the area.  The office gets congested as people are either waiting for the tour to begin or waiting to get tickets.  Parking in the area is dear.  It cost us $29 to park for the short time we were there.

title: Beautiful
text: There are so many good harvard stories, it is completely worth it to stick around and take a guided tour. Food is cheap and delicious!

title: Get schooled...
text: We got our smarts on when we visited Harvard.  We touched his John Harvard's shoe for good luck, walked around the campus and the town and felt pretty awesome doing so.  Great shops, beautiful surrounds. Well worth the visit.

title: Broadway Marketplace
text: While ar Harvard, take time for a great lunch at Broadway Marketplace.  Excellent fresh food to eat, takeway or picnic!

title: Amazing
text: The buildings and garden on the campus are amazing, I really enjoyed my visit there. I took the guided tour, because I wanted to know a bit more about Harvard history and it was awesome, our tour guide was Samantha, she was really nice, had very interesting facts and some pretty funny histories too. Definitely kept the group interested. Totally recommend it.

title: What a gorgeous place to walk around
text: Even if you don't go to school here, this is a great place to just hang around. Harvard Yard is a place i can sit for hours. There is free wifi and loads of people watching. Try to catch one of the passing tours...they are all so funny!

title: Same ugly architecture
text: It was almost impossible to visit any of the buildings. They all looked exactly alike? I have been to many ivy league colleges and found them to have a variety of interesting looking buildings, not Harvard.

title: Quite boring, architectures in quite similar style.
text:
I visited there with my friend in a local tour and Harvard University was one of the spot.
The history of it was not interesting at all to me, I found some of the buildings were building in the similar style.
The story of the school was quite interesting instead, for example like the pig-head gate curse and Mr. Harvard's statue's one.
I even found that hanging outside the campus was even more interesting than what we had done inside it.
Maybe I am not that kind of person who is so into how a university was from.

title: Okay, Not Awesome
text: We did a self guided tour using their Yardtour app. If you are in the area it is definitely worth a visit, but if you are short on time, you can skip it. There isn't that much to "see"-  I found Yale prettier - but you may want to go just because it is Harvard.

title: Great tour and very interesting
text:
The grounds are spectacular and the buildings steeped in history.
We decided to take the tour guided by one of the students.  Very interesting as you also caught glimpses of the school from his perspective.  
Interesting to find out also that he was lucky enough to be here on scholarship (although I don't think they call it that) but basically not at any cost to him.  Of course he must have been an exceptionally bright fellow as only  a small percentage of applicants get accepted.
Very enjoyable-glad we did it.

title: Harvard. You should visit but it is nothing that special.
text: I live in a town with an old urban university, not as old as Harvard, but old none the less.  Harvard was fun to visit and the buildings are interesting but in the end it is not hugely special. Chalk it up as something you should do when travelling to Boston but you only need 3 to 4 hours. Note that there is expensive meter parking and different blocks have different maximum times. The maximum of the maximums is 2 hours. There are garages but you can take the subway right into to Harvard Square.

title: #tourofivies
text: My wife and I were in the boston area for a RedSox game and decided to stop by Harvard and look around. It seemed like any other college town. The area was more tourist friendly than other areas and it seemed as though there were many more people doing what we were doing (looking around Harvard) than I expected. Glad we did it.

title: Great Tour
text: We decided to visit Harvard University & glad we did. We took the red line subway from our hotel. We were staying in Beacon Hill section & had a pleasant 10 min ride to the Harvard station. As you exit the train station to your right is a tour for $10 given by Harvard students. The tours start at 10:30 & run until 3:30 every half hour. Our tour guide, Francesca, was very informative, interacted with the group, and had a lot of information to share. The tour lasts about an hour & is held outside. The area around Harvard had plenty of shopping & restaurants as well.

title: It's Harvard.....
text: Took the Subway to Harvard and well what can one say.. It was Harvard.  A must see if you are in Boston simply because it is the oldest university,the alumni, and the famous people that started there and then left.. The libraries are amazing.  It is all Red as we learned that the color is Crimson in memory of the blood shed during the Revolutionary War.  We did not take a guided tour but walked the campus.  Great architecture and plenty of shops and places to eat.

title: One of those places you visit when in Boston
text: The entire place is worth the visit.  Tradition, history, atmosphere. Take a slow walk, download the apps, hear all about the yard.  Its easy to get to if you are taking the train from Boston

title: horribly disappointing
text: As a university student, I could not have been more disappointed in the Harvard campus. It lacked flow, the paths seemed to randomly go in any direction, other than three buildings, the rest looked the same, a very plain red brick. Not impressed at all. As the oldest school in America I would've expected a lot more to come from the grounds. Overall, not worth the trip up to Cambridge to visit the campus, you're really not missing out on much.

title: A must on any visit to Boston
text: I loved my tour of Harvard. This is a free tour given by a student. It was an hour packed with information and insights on the history of Harvard & a sneak peak into life as a Harvard student. I loved it!

title: Beautiful historic University
text:
We walked through the grounds of Harvard University when we went to brunch at the Sheraton Commander Hotel.  We were amazed at how beautiful the university grounds are.  

Some of the architecture is spectacular and the grounds are really pretty.  Having only seen the universities in Sydney and some of the regional NSW universities back home, none of the Australian campuses compare to the history of Harvard.

title: Harvard Yard (Quad) A Must For Everyone
text: I feel so at home when I'm in the Harvard Yard (quad) they've got bright colored chairs to lounge in.

title: Finally saw Harvard
text: Visited friend on Broadway in Cambridge. A short walk up Broadway past exquisite old New England Victorian Colonial homes, each bigger and more unique than the last, if that is possible, to arrive at Harvard itself. FInally took the time to wander the campus with its trees and unique buildings. What a pleasure.

title: Finally made it
text: To finally stand in the yard and take in the atmosphere was awesome. We followed the Tripadvisor walking tour and had a lovely overview. Highly recommeded.

title: It is what it is.
text: We voted it a five because although there are many other beautiful college campuses in the world to see, well, it's Harvard. If nothing else, you should see it because it's....Harvard. Lots of places to eat and cool architecture in the area. Make sure to stop by the Natural History museum while there.

title: Great tour
text: I did the paid tour of Harvard. The place is hugee and I thought it would be better to have a guided tour. My tour guide was Samantha and she was just great!! Our group was pretty big that day but Sam was able to engage everyone and boy did she have a loud voice! Lol! No way anyone could say they could not hear what she was saying. Harvard is so full of history! A really great tour to check out! It is worth the $10 in my opinion!

title: pretentious
text: even for a quick visit. most of campus is under lock and key, the place has a keep out vibe. prefer MIT

title: Quick relaxing stroll around the campus
text: We passed through Boston on our way to Niagara Falls and took a quick break at Harvard U. It took us quite a while to find a parking and to find the entrance to the campus. The campus was quiet and peaceful. We were there in late afternoon and the wind was very cool. It was quite a relaxing stroll around. Too bad we don't have someone who was familiar with the place to tour us around.

title: Do not rub the foot of John Harvard statue...
text:
(5) ... because this statue is frequently peed upon for good luck. It is also not John Harvard - no one knows how he looked.

(4) do take a photo at the steps of the Widener Library. It is a memorial to Harry Widener, who perished with the Titanic in 1912. Harry has a study room inside, and a desk with  a vase replenished with fresh flowers every day. The library has 50 miles of shelves and Harvard students aim to make out among the shelves once before graduating.

(3) do visit Harvard Yard during Winter - the snowmen outside the freshmen halls range from Easter Island statue lookalikes to Picasso-esque women.

(2) do enjoy Harvard Yard on a Sunday morning - the bells of Memorial Church ring first, then near to noon, the bells of Lowell Hall chime fantastically for about an hour. In between there is quiet and beauty, birds, squirrels and rabbits.

(1) do visit on Moving- in Day (end Aug). See the freshmen from all over the US and the world move in to the freshmen halls which surround The Yard. There is a festive air. Student advisors are on hand to tell visitors all about Harvard and various groups give out Harvard memorabilia, chilled lemonade and brochures.

title: Worth a quick train ride to Cambridge
text: We wanted to see Cambridge and why not start at Harvard?  It was move in day for summer school, so it was fun to see all the students and their parents.  Made us realize that Harvard students aren't that different from the rest of us - all of them have that deer in headlights look the first day.  The campus was beautiful and we enjoyed looking at all the buildings.  It was easy to get to via the metro and worth an hour or so on a nice afternoon.

title: Nice place
text: Really it is a nice place, I have been there in the summer and it was really pleasant, there were  a lot of students in the yard, the day was really enjoyable.

title: Escorted tour of campus - Harvard university
text:
The tour guides are located in the main square in Cambridge MA and for 10# per head, small groups are given a tour of Harvard University campus.
Our guide on May 29th was Eli - a student who was knowledgeable and amusing. A visit on our own would have been very superficial so we feel the money was well spend and made an enjoyable afternoon.

title: breathtaking escape
text: easy access to the quad by train. able to stroll leisurely through the garden. the library with marble pillars is breathtaking

title: Fantastic walk
text: Loved the architecture, the shops near Harvard square, the faculty of sciences's mini-museum (a hidden gem with the original Mark I computer from the 40s) and much more. Well worth the visit and accessible by subway.

title: Have to do it if you're in Boston
text: Interesting experience to see what all the hype is about.  Go touch the foot of the John Harvard statue for good luck.  Breathe in all of the history.  People watch and think to yourself are they really that much smarter than you are?

title: Cambridge green space
text: We had dinner reservations in the area but arrived early so we walked around Harvard Yard which was in preparation for their graduation.  Lovely green space, lots of places to walk, sculptures to see, benches to relax on.  We even saw a wild bunny!!

title: Harvard, an amazing place
text: Any trip to Boston is not complete without a trip across the Charles River to Harvard University. The school is historic and amazing, but the quaint area of Cambridge is a joy as well. We enjoy discovering new restaurants and sites each time we return to visit our daughter who is a student at Harvard.

title: The closest i'll ever get to Harvard
text: The university is majestic and are filled with visitors. It is easily found but the people in Harvard are not so friendly. Worth visiting though :)

title: Harvard Student tour
text: A  trip via the subway to Harvard on the Red Line is certainly worth a visit. This university dates back to 1636 . The one hour tour of the University Square and a number of other buildings is conducted by current students. Our guide was Eli who was just great, a touch of theater and 2 years experience as a student gave us an insight of the Universities history, and current life as a student. A great visit.

title: Very different from what you might expect
text: I'm not sure what I expected, but what we found on a Sunday afternoon was a cool place with laid back people content to do their own thing. From competitive chess matches you are welcome to watch to semi-homeless musicians and mac writing professor types, this is the kind of place you can wear a fedora or put flowers in your hair. Great little shops around, I suggest the dessert shop Finale, it was Wiked Pissah.

title: Beautiful College Campus
text: Clearly modelled on Oxford and Cambridge Universities in the UK, with their Quads and Courts, Harvard Yard exudes pre-eminence - which Harvard has in abundance. There are walking tours, but it is good enough just to wander around at a leisurely pace and soak it in.

title: A real disappointment
text: This place is world-famous, but why? Where is it? There's this big yard with green grass and lots of buildings and people wearing funny hats, but there's no there there, if you know what I mean. I kept asking students where Harvard University is, and they kept saying "Right here!" But I left no smarter than when I arrived.

title: All that crimson gets tiresome
text: I happened to be there on their so-called "Commencement Day" and there were all sorts of people wearing silly hats and Hogwarts-style robes. What gives? Also, speeches are dull. It's hard to believe that all those people are really that smart. Harvard must hand out diplomas like politicians hand out promises.

title: A timeless place
text: You almost forget what year it is when you stop by in the Yard. The buildings, trees and even the students seem like they've been there forever and you can easily blend in. In the summer there are chairs on the lawn that are great to rest in and watch people go by.

title: Son's Last graduation from Harvard--Hooray!!
text: We were here 3 years ago for our son's Harvard College Graduation & this was his HLS Graduation. So, really not a visit, but a pleasant few days of events in a classical university setting, worth a visit!

title: What a Campus
text: This campus is gorgeous.  We walked all around.  Luckily we had an alum with us which gave us a personalized tour and much info.  We ate near campus and there is an ambience that is heartfelt.

title: Old Center of Oldest American University
text: Where Harvard began in 1636. Oldest buildings in university. Combines dormitories, libraries, Memorial Church, classroom buildings. Although the Harvard Yard is only a small portion if Harvard, it conveys the essence v

title: Greatest University in World
text: Student Led Tours hit the highlights of oldest American university & convey flavor of student life. Incredible collections of museums at Harvard. Also fascinating history of architecture in its buildings.

title: Feels like fun at the United Nations.
text: We were there during graduation week which meant that it was crowded but full of people from all over the world having a wonderful time. Nice to revisit the oldest university in the United States.

title: history & present meet in Harvard Yard
text: It's true that Harvard Yard -- there are two, actually, old and new yards -- are the center of a twenty first century campus. at times they are filled with the day to day doings of current students. there are times, though, especially when it's quiet, that you can feel the presence of those, recent and centuries ago, who've walked this place before you.

title: Great campus
text:
If you like education and university life you should go there.
historical campus and you will see the great harvard university

title: A city within a city
text: It is interesting driving and walking through the university area, one minute you are near lecture buildings the next you are walking through shops and restaurants and amongst student accommodation.

title: Great experience
text: Perfect, the day was amazing the people are fantastic, everything made the day perfect.  Service excellent!  I love the Yard!

title: Food Carts & Historic Campus
text:
Try and time your trip here to include lunch at the food trucks so you can take in the activity of campus life. There were three food options when I visited, and I believe all accepted both credit cards and cash (though you don't get a receipt, so if you're there for work make sure you use the email receipt option. Campus is beautiful and there are many colorful chairs in the open yard space, if you don't want to lounge in the grass and eat lunch, which is something I highly recommend. 

I didn't take the tour, but enjoyed wondering around campus. I'm at another ivy league school, so beautiful old building's and history are something I'm used to, but it was still well worth the trip up to Cambridge!

title: Architecture, History, Education
text: The architecture on the grounds of Harvard University is diverse and beautiful.  Make sure to take your picture next to John Harvard Statue and see the beautiful library, church, and amazing gothic dining hall/theatre building.

title: Wow! So picturesque. .....way more than I expected
text: I had a few hours tip kill, so I hopped on the red line. Went to MIT and Harvard. While MIT had some very funky architecture, Harvard is just plain unbelievable. The old buildings and all of the architecture will blow your mind. I could've spent 2-3 more hours here......I will post some of the 50 pics on here.....I was blown away! Go here or you will regret it..

title: Put this on you bucket list
text: My family wanted to see the campus.  I really had no desire, but I am so glad I went.  The campus is absolutely stunning with old buildings and beautiful architecture.  Memorial Hall was breathtakingly beautiful, my camera could never capture its beauty.  I can't recommend going enough just to see that hallway.

title: Pleasant walk around campus
text: Walked onto grounds from Harvard Square T Redline station.  Could have used a campus map although we eventually found one or two somewhere in the law faculty.  Washrooms and a cafeteria were in the Science Center.  Lovely with the trees flowering.

title: You can always say you went to Harvard
text:
A trip to Greater Boston isn't really complete without visiting one of the most famous universities in the world. Particularly if you're from the western part of North America, the age of some of the  the buildings alone will keep you interested. (Harvard was founded in 1636) We wandered down the hallways of one of the older buildings, and overheard a student being examined by a panel of professors - in Latin. There are several good places on campus and nearby to grab some good souvenirs like the requisite t-shirt or hoodie. 
A tip: if you want the true student experience, schedule your visit over lunch, and eat in the freshmen's cafeteria. Online reviews of the food rate it as good/not great. These are obviously people who haven't gone to school elsewhere; by cafeteria standards it's above par. The attraction is the room itself, called the Memorial Hall, built to honor the Harvard Alumni who perished during the American Civil War in defence of the Union. It's quite the building, and the meal is reasonably priced.

title: Perfect visit
text: This is a charismatic, enlightening and exciting area to visit. The tour led by Harvard scholars was well presented and gave visitors a glimpse of life at Harvard. The cafes and store around Harvard Square are convenient with friendly service. One could easily spend an entire day at the Coop

title: Classic College "Quad" But Beware the Tourists
text: At times, it seems as if the tourists crowding around John Harvard's statue and rubbing his toe (rumor has it that it is not really rubbing that has caused the toe to be shiny, but certain bodily fluids surreptitiously deposited in the dark of night) and snapping photos.  Best to walk around the permitter and soak in the history.  The Harvard walking tour app for your phone is a good companion.

title: It is world renown, for a good reason
text: It's Harvard.  Yes, folks here can be pretentious I suppose, but every single student and staff member I met seemed really genuinely happy to be here and appreciated what an amazing and historical place this really is.

title: Great for having a walk
text: Take the 50 minutes tour. If not, just walk Arround and watch all the old buildings and beautifull churches. Also have lunch at shake shack hamburgers in Harvard square.

title: Students/Academics can access libraries if you come prepared
text:
Harvard is a beautiful campus to wander with its historic buildings and spacious grounds. 

As a foreign PhD students and university lecturer it is possible to gain access to the many libraries as a "visiting researcher" - I took a simple letter from my university and with my passport was able to get free 3 month access to both the standard libraries and the Special Collections from the Library Privileges Office. Even for just a 2 day visit it was great to be able to go inside and see the immense collections, as well as read some 400+ year old books that I have not been able to find copies of at home.

title: Harvard -- Nothing More Needs to be Said!!!
text: My wife and I visited Harvard where our son is in his second year at Harvard Law School.  The campus is historic, not only as one of the oldest universities in America, but also because of the many notable people who have attended Harvard, including President John F. Kennedy.  Harvard Square, which is the open space at the center of the university, offers a quiet place to reflect on your visit to Harvard.

title: Historic Harvard
text: People visiting the Boston area like going to visit Harvard because of Harvard, but also because of Harvard Square. Haavard is historic with lovely buildings and spacious quadrangles to walk around on a sunny day. The students are busy, but friendly. Most people do not know however, that there are several museums on the harvard campus. They cannot compete with Boston's Museum of Science and Museum of Fine Arts.  Harvard square is an always active  milieu with panhandlers, restaurants, street musicians and shops. A ride on the T can augment this visit if there is time and it is convenient.

title: Such history!
text:
We took in several museums (we especially liked the natural history museum, and the display of historic scientific instruments in the Science Center) and enjoyed walking around on our own.  

We also did an information session and tour.  The information session was in Sanders Theatre, which is a beautiful building.  The tour was led by 2 current students, and they gave us a good perspective on the House system and other aspects of the university.

title: A beautiful walk
text: Wandering around Harvard's historic campus is very relaxing...(unless you are a student stressing out because of exams, of course). There's plenty of trees and grass and at just a few minutes away from the subway stop, you find yourself wandering around a beautiful and old campus where there's hardly any noise from cars and where the vibe is completely different from anywhere else in the Boston area.

title: Great for a free stroll, wonderful museums
text: Strolling through the yard is a must for visitors and if you have kids gives them a chance to run around.  Access to the libraries etc. is available but you have to sign in and show ID.  The Harvard Museums are incredible and really reasonably priced.  The Museum of Natural History really engages children as well.

title: There are several tours
text:
The admissions tour can be done through the admissions office.  The regular Harvard Tour which is free can be arranged at the Holyoke Center.  And the funny spoof but enlightening tour can be arranged from venders in Harvard Square or online.

Harvard is a place of History and interesting buildings.  You will enjoy it if those are your interests

title: Don't bother unless you are planning to apply.
text: It looks like any other university. I have lived in Cambridge for more than 50 years and attended graduate school at Harvard. Go to the Museum of Natural History, the Sackler Museum but the University itself is boring.

title: Not much to see
text: I didn't get a chance to visit any of the Harvard Museums but the campus itself looks like any other part of New England: brick buildings with white roof and trimmings around quaint grassy courtyards and squares. The free tour is a waste of time: you go nowhere that is not already publicly accessible and learn nothing you don't get from signs or guidebooks. It was nice to visit such a famous place and to see the John Harvard statue but it is a stop in Boston that can easily be skipped.

title: OK, I was a grad student there for 6 years and my son was just accepted!
text: I loved living at Harvard as a tutor at Lowell House and studying there in the Archaeology wing. I will agree with many others that it is the top university in the world. Just as I enjoyed visiting Cambridge University in England many years ago, I would say that anyone visiting Boston should visit Harvard. I have photographed the sights of Harvard in all seasons, but I enjoyed the snow on the elaborate wrought iron fences around the yard the most. The Head of the Charles Regatta is an opportunity for a brilliant cavalcade of color as the crews race on the Charles. A football game creates tail gating like you have never seen. I look forward to visiting my son as he starts his adventure at Harvard.

title: A must see!
text: Visiting Harvard was on my bucket-list. They have a visitors center that offers tours every hour on the hour. That was perfect! Our student tour guide was very knowledgeable and took us all across the campus. We learned quite a bit of history and information about the school and the community. Being from the south, Ivy League schools appear so distant and unobtainable, but the feel of the environment made you feel that anything is possible with hard work. I'd definitely recommend the tour and recommend walking around Harvard Square. They have tons of shops and restaurants to visit. The T rail stops right at the front gate too. Also visit the student-ran book store too. They have way cheaper prices that others.

title: Really?  Why Bother?
text:
Maybe it's because I've lived near Harvard for 25 years.  Maybe it's because the institution has been coasting on its reputation for a century.  Maybe it's because I read one story after another in the local papers about its attempts to manipulate the community.  But there's not that much to see here.  Harvard's grounds are not that attractive -- not nearly so as any of a hundred campuses across the country.  One can listen to the stories of past notables.  Or one can consider the embarrassments of the current institution -- the B-School which helped drag down the economy, the Ed-School which has mucked up the system of public education in this country. 

Want to go for a place for a nice walk?  Try the Fresh Pond Reservoir, the Minuteman Bike Trial, the Charles River trails, or the Mt. Auburn Cemetery.  Wander around a bit at Harvard if you want to see some stodgy, rather unattractive buildings, but god help you if you spend money for a tour. Does Harvard need $10 to promote its mythology when it has a $30 billion endowment?  I think not.

title: the US version of Oxford
text: the setting by Charles River helps, as did the sunshine today, but the money clearly lavished on restoring tower tops pays off as the scenery as one drives around the University is attractive. Liked Mr Harvard and his gold shoe which duly touched.

title: Great walking tour of Harvard
text:
We completed a terrific tour of Harvard University.  Hannah a student at the uni was our tour guide and explained the history of the place and answered all questions with great expansion.  Some fantastic historical buildings throughout the grounds.  Good to see where 'Facebook' was created!!  If you do the Boston Duck tour, there is no additional fee for the tour.
Easy to get to via the subway and worth the trip if you have some time to spare in Boston.

title: Hahvahd Tour
text:
We shunned the free tour and opted for the Hahvahd Tour run by students - cost $10 per person and worth it too! Our tour guide Pryanka was excellent. She had a great insight into the history of the University and mixed fact with myth in a very entertaining way.

The free map provided with the tour points you into the excellent delights the surrounding streets have to offer. We happily spent a whole day in the area.

title: Quick visit
text: I took the subway to the campus, It was quite convenient. Had a walk around the square as well. You won't be able to go inside the library though.

title: American dream
text:
Definiely the place you want to visit when you go in Boston. Some free tours are organised around campus some mornigs ( I did mine during the summer). Visit the place were the leaders of tomorrow's are getting train!
Also don't forget to touch the foot of the statue as it gives you luck

title: beautiful place
text: The Harvard University Campus is such a nice place to visit with nice gardens and old buildings. Everything is clean and neat.

title: Every student shall see it
text: Harvard is not only one of the oldest but also the best university in the world, so every student shall see it if they visit Cambridge. The Harvard Yard represents the historic and traditional side of Harvard, while the campus behind is the center of knowledge and research. Many libraries with different names and functions are located in the yard and the campus, so if you have time, you should pay a visit there. Labs and museums are also impressive

title: Historic Campus
text: Harvard Yard is the historic center of Harvard University. The buildings are very impressive. Their are a lot of very good colleges that could fit their entire campus in Harvard Yard - which is now just a small part of the total Harvard University presence in Cambridge, MA.

title: What a joy
text: Stroll around the yard.  Take pictures of the tourists taking pictures. Visit the statue of the three lies - which has become a cult object. Soak in the ambiance. Read the quote by Emerson on the philosophy building.

title: a rich stroll
text: Walking through Harvard Yard is an oasis from the city.  The grand old structures covered in ivy, the  old trees, and the overall feeling of hope.

title: Harvard is the dream University !
text: We took the walking tour in Harvard.  There was so much to see and learn about this University.  We walked around for almost two hours everything was so interesting.  We finished the tour at a souvenir store.

title: Impressive Historical Institution
text: We got a private tour from the young man we are acquainted with there, so got to see things others wouldn't have.  The dining hall is the most impressive place of all. It's like a massive cathederal.  We viewed the entire sports complex, saw the dorms, statue of John Harvard and the classroom buildings.  Very impressive and beautiful grounds even in the winter.

title: Get your photo rubbing John Harvard's shoe
text:
It doesn't matter what time of day you walk through the yard. 7am, 11pm, -15 degrees outside, 100 degrees, doesn't mater. People will be taking their picture with John Harvard and his foot. So don't feel like you won't fit in because you're not a college student, you'll be right at home in the yard. 

I think tours leave hourly from the Holyoke Center, you can always just join one going on while you're walking by!

title: Take the free tour
text: We stopped in to see Harvard and were pleased to find out that the students union offers free tours of Harvard Yard. It gave us some of the history of the place. It was a very interesting way to spend the hour. For shopping go to the co-op for clothes and souvenirs. Their is a separate co-op that is an excellent bookstore. Try to stop in both stores.

title: Harvard, I came, I saw ....
text: Finally we were at Harvard, the dream educational institute for academics all over the world! We went thorugh the website and they had during summer only one info session a day but no apopintments were necessary. Arriving the prestigiouis hall was a bit of a trouble as the campus is huge with many competing buildings but this one is Church shaped and cannot be missed.

title: It is Harvard...
text: America's oldest and arguably most famous university located just outside Boston Massachusetts has a cozy campus with a rich history.  The area is nice and quiet, but one would expect more from the campus.  Other campuses have more to offer visitors and I would imagine students and faculty.  I am a big fan of architecture and unique buildings, but there was not much to offer.  Maybe the university is steep in the tradition and history and keep true to that identity which I can appreciate.  I am sure if I spent more time in the area I would find the appeal, but first impressions leave with the overrated label.

title: Love Story
text: In good weather, head hear to check out the campus and see where Love Story was filmed.  Remember that movie?

title: HARVARD... The name speaks for itself.
text: This is the quintessential university in the country.  The campus is fantastic, Harvard Square is picturesque and fun with all the shops.  A great place to wander around in good weather.  Of course, a great place to go to school if you're smart enough to get in.

title: Harvard University
text: The Subway takes you all the way to Harvard from downtown Boston. I took a one hour guided tour by a university student. To hear stories about  J.F. Kennedy and Mark Zuckerberg was well worth the extra $15.

title: A Peaceful Place with History, Charm and Culture
text: Strolling around the Harvard campus is a wonderful way to get a sense of one of the nation's finest educational institutions. If you have time, check out the glass reproductions of botanical specimens in the Peabody Museum.

title: Great place for a walk-around
text: The classically styled buildings offer a sensory experience of how it might be to spend study time here.  Harvard Yards is a great place for a stroll, or in summer, a sit on the grass.  Bustles with life even in winter, and the restaurants and cafes are minutes away if you need refreshers

title: Nice
text: Beautiful to walk though, peaceful.  School just started so campus was full of new and old students.  Lots of dreams in their eyes !

title: Great visit
text: A stunning campus and a great local town meant we had a really good visit here which is excellent for people watching and just soaking up the atmosphere of this place which is amazing. This must be great for students and an amazing place to study in, the buildings are beautiful and it is very peaceful during December. You can just sit down, close your eyes and imagine what it must be like when in term time. Very pleased we made this visit.

title: Great experience!
text: I was lucky enough to recently attend a Stephen King speaking engagement on the campus. Absolutely beautiful campus and the architecture is breathtaking. Whether you are attending school, a function or just taking a walk, do yourself a favor and take in all the rich history these grounds have to offer.

title: Nothing like having a pic nion their gardens ...
text:
Grab some food, bring a blanket and enjoy watching people walk by while you eat your lunch or drink your coffee.
Take the time to vsit the archeological site where students are digging and finding the old university setlers.
Enjoy
Moro

title: Top University worldwide
text: Just walking around admiring the beautiful surroundings will make you feel energized and optimistic. No sondear Why innovation flourishes among all this brillante minds.

title: Makes you feel clever!
text: Lovely for a stroll round campus when the leaves are changing.  All the buildings are pretty and you find yourself looking up whilst you’re walking round.  Makes you feel more clever than you are just through having a wander!  There are a few nice shops to look in along the main street of Harvard.

title: I went to Harvard..
text:
Yes I went to Harvard for a visit!!  A walk through the Harvard Yard it well worth doing - we went in late October so the autumn colours added to the sense grandeur of this institution and the grounds.  Students were also on campus as it was term time and there was a sense of things happening when classes finished and students came out of the buildings and moved about the grounds to their next class.  If you have time visit the Memorial Church and stand in front of Widener Library & take in the enormity of this building and of course don't forget to touch the foot on the John Harvard Statue.
There is a walking tour which is conducted by students and is called Hahvahd Tour - it starts from just outside the Harvard T stop - if I had know about this before arriving I would have connected with this tour as it looked like it was fun and informative the couple of times I crossed paths with the tour group on my walk through the campus.  There is a small cost if you join a tour, but just walking through the campus grounds is free.

title: Glad we went
text: Very elegant establishment with a combination of Architectural styles. I would like to have seen more but fundamentally this is a highly privileged place of education and it certainly looks and feels like one...Glad we've been there to see it.

title: Visit the Yard
text: A slow walk through Harvard Yard may give you a sense of the quiet, peaceful, intensity of this college.  A visit in the autumn is probably best -- students walking to and from classes, and colored leaves on the many trees.  Rub the toe of John Harvard's boot for luck.  If you have time, arrange before your visit for a tour, guided by one of the current students -- they're knowledgeable, and funny.

title: Get the App!
text:
You need to download the app available via Itunes or Harvard's website.
If you are using Android, download the Boston city guide from Tripadvisor and you will find the Harvard Yard Tour and its great!
Free Wifi available on campus, makes your visit so much more enjoyable and interactive with all the Historic infomation you can find on the App.
Best way to get there is with the T red line, you get off right at Harvard Square. Walking along surrounding streets is also great, nice neighborhood and safe.

title: Nice folliage
text: It is beautiful all the time but during autumn, it's even better with the leaves turning red and yellow.

title: Feels genius
text: Harvard yard was so classy and beautiful that just by going there made me feel like a genius.

title: the yard gives people inspiration, the museum of glass flowers is worthwhile to see
text: I like the colorful chairs in the yard, which can inspired people, but there are not many beautiful building, there is a student canteen which is gorgeous, but it only allows student to enter. As I have a friend who works in Harvard, so I can visit the museum for free, it normally seems costs $12 (you may double check it for sure), but the glass flowers exhibition is really worthwhile to see, the plants were made with glass, but they are so real that you may be unable to tell the difference from the real one just by seeing with eyes.

title: If you're in the area...
text: ...it's on the list of things to see in Boston.  One of America's iconic institution.  We visited one of the original yards, & saw the Statue of the Three Lies, saw some of the older buildings and library.  But the campus is massive...as a Fringe junkie it would have been nice to see the portion they used for filming, but we were part of a larger tour & that wasn't on the agenda. :)

title: Harvard University
text: If you plan on visiting Cambridge, don't skip going to Harvard Yard or taking the tour of the campus.  This tour is well worth it.  I had family visit from overseas and this was a staple they wanted to see.  Everyone around the world knows about Harvard University.  The campus is lovely and well worth it.

title: Harvard University
text: If ever there was a brand name in colleges, Harvard is it. The campus is well worth the visit from "Harvard Yard" where the freshmen are housed, to Widener Library, named after a victim of the Titanic, to Memorial Hall, the monument to Harvard men who died (on the Northern side) of the Civil War. The campus stretches along the Charles River with the beautiful Business School across from the Cambridge side. The Fogg Art Museum is closed right now, under renovation but the Peabody Museum of Natural History is open and filled with interesting things. The famous Glass Flowers are found there. Buildings by IM Pei and LeCorbusier can be found as well as those from early architects such as Henry Hobson Richardson. After the visit, wander the stores of Harvard Square and have lunch in one of the many restaurants.

title: Harvard visit and Yard
text: Since visitors cannot enter Harvard buildings, the best way to taste the spirit of this great university is to visit the yard, its surroundings and Harvard Square.

title: Harvard yard --so lovely..
text:
if you plan to visit Cambridge, don't miss the Harvard Yard. Just to see young people walking around the paths, through beautiful trees and lawns to get to classes and the monumental Widener Library, is exhilarating.  Very easy to reach on the T (public transport.) Guided tours will tell you that the much visited statue of John harvard has nothing to do with the man ! it's charming all the same.
One can combine this visit with another at MIT, or with having a meal around Harvard Square. So time of visit can vary from one to four hours.

title: It is Harvard
text: Harvard university is different to MIT and Tufts. It does not have a university feel to it but rather you feel like you are in a different city somewhere in Europe. The architecture and the history is quite apparent. It is a must see. I would recommend anytime before October because therevis always something going on which can really enhance your visit. However you cannot you will still enjoy it.

title: Think smart, look smart
text: Harvard is a large institution with lots to see. Architecture (old and new), outdoor spaces (Harvard yard, Radcliffe yard, area around the law school, etc., the Harvard coop store,  and some fun museums. Get a map, be curious, take a tour and imagine a few hundred years of education taking place…HOw long you stay depends on how interested you are in meandering around an urban campus.

title: Ivy League
text: The various colleges, museums, and shops span over the Charles River. Trendy filled with Great history and culture

title: SO MUCH  HISTORY IN  ONE  PLACE
text: But  You  really  cannot  "pahk your  cah in Hahvard Yahd"  It is  a  quadrangle of  residence  halls.  Great  for  walking   and  for  walking  your  bike  through.  The  John  Harvard  Statue is  a  popular  photo  op.

title: Must see on a visit to Boston and Cambridge
text:
If you go to Boston, you must go to Harvard University.  It is easily accessible by train, but we were driving and had no difficulties getting a park nearby.  I had been before with a tour, so this time we just wandered, and really enjoyed the experience.  Do some reading beforehand about John Harvard, the library which burnt down and the candle story, the massive library just to name a few, and you will appreciate it so much more.  

Full of history and amazing achievement, it is worth a visit for a few hours, and you can finish with a stop at the COOP where you can buy great memorabilia, and a reasonably priced coffee and sandwich at the cafe upstairs, as there isn't much choice in the food department downstairs on the Square.

title: Just another nice university campus
text: You can't go in any buildings, which is understandable for safety. Your best bet is to take guided tour if you want to hear about any history. T stop is basically under the university.

title: Worth a visit
text: We were looking for a grand entrance to Harvard.  But we found only a small gate leading to the university.  It was a sunny fall day which made it very pleasant to visit the campus.  The Statue of John Harvard was a popular site for photography.  A mixture of old and new architectures in the campus.  Heard so much about it and well worth a visit while touring Boston.

title: Nice fall visit
text: Cool brisk weather, fall leaves makes strolling through Harvard a great afternoon activity. It sprawls along a fairly big area. Some students offer a tour and it is a nice option.

title: Harvard Tour- Overall Disappointing
text:
We set out to compare both the Yale and Harvard campus tours within a couple days time. There are a few options for tours of Harvard but we elected the official tour provided by current students. This was apples to apples to the Yale tour we took. 

We were expecting much more from the Harvard tour. Unfortunately, it was rather boring as compared to the Yale tour. Perhaps it was the guide, but there were few fun, interesting historical stories. The tour was so dry, I think we would have had a better experience just roaming on our own. 

Harvard Yard is pretty with nice grassy areas and trees. It had colorful chairs in the center of the grass where students can hang out. There are a lot of historical buildings but the architecture isn't nearly as interesting as that of Yale. It was all just a little disappointing but we are glad we did it. Honestly, the campus is nothing special compared to many other campuses we have attended or explored. 

If we were students comparing the schools and taking the tours, we'd pick Yale hands down. 

Another note, there are no parking lots in the area. You have to use metered parking which is a max of 2 hours and accepts only quarters. If you plan on touring around, you will need to have quarters handy and be ready to make your way back to the meter a few times to add time.

title: Harvard Tour- Just Okay!
text:
We set out to compare both the Yale and Harvard campus tours within a couple days time. There are a few options for tours of Harvard but we elected the official tour provided by current students.  This was apples to apples to the Yale tour we took. 

We were expecting much more from the Harvard tour. Unfortunately, it was rather boring as compared to the Yale tour. Perhaps it was the guide, but there were few fun, interesting historical stories. The tour was so dry, I think we would have had a better experience just roaming on our own. 

Harvard Yard is pretty with nice grassy areas and trees. It had colorful chairs in the center of the grass where students can hang out. There are a lot of historical buildings but the architecture isn't nearly as interesting as that of Yale. It was all just a little disappointing but we are glad we did it. Honestly, the campus is nothing special compared to many other campuses we have attended or explored. 

If we were students comparing the schools and taking the tours, we'd pick Yale hands down. 

Another note, there are no parking lots in the area. You have to use metered parking which is a max of 2 hours and accepts only quarters. If you plan on touring around, you will need to have quarters handy and be ready to make your way back to the meter a few times to add time.

title: Impressive
text: My girlfriend and I went on a self guided tour of Harvard University at around 10:00 p.m. on Thursday evening, October 3, 2013.  Fortunately, it was not raining.  I must say that it took a while to find parking at Harvard Square, even at this time of night.  In any case, we walked the campus for about an hour and could have easily got lost.  This university is spread out like a small city.  Of course, the buildings here have such architectural beauty.  What surprised me is that the students I spoke with for directions were all so polite.  One even went out of his way to let us into the Harvard Law School library using his student key card.  Apparently this library is open all the time  during school hours.  It was a pleasure to see one of America's finest universities firsthand.

title: I truly enjoyed the Campus
text: I had the opportunity to visit Harvard during a business travel and I was echanted by the autumn colors of the Harvard Yard. I went on Saturday from Boston, it's well connected via train and next to the Station. The Campus is open to visitors in the common areas and I could visit the church and some open classrooms. Everywhere an incredible quiet and a sense of respect.

title: What is great about America
text:
Just walking on the campus made us feel smarter, and proud.
Harvard University is how I always imagined- structured. Intellectual, momentous. It truly made me realize how wonderful our educational system could and should be.
The campus was buzzing with young, enthusiastic minds, the structures were statuesque, and the grounds beautiful.
The day we went it was cold and breezy. The leaves we're kicking around, which made the experience that much more surreal.

title: Institute of Higher learning
text: Harvard is very prestigious, both educationally and historically.  It offers opportunities in all professional fields to those who are willing to study hard and apply their skills in and out of this university.  I enjoyed the varied living and adaptive centers for all levels whether family or single.  Harvard offers many benefits for those who achieve a doctorates in their specified fields.

title: Great but missed the tour
text: If you are in the area be sure to catch a tour of the university. We were there on a Sunday and didn't get a tour of the campus and were disappointed. Take the train as parking is horrible and you won't be able to see anything from the car. Lessons learned from our trip!

title: Excelent visit
text:
I highly recommend while visiting Boston to go see Harvard University. 
As you get off the subway you will see some students from HU are there to offer a free guide while telling some of their personal experiences. This is great. 
You can walk all around the campus and the outsides which are also beautiful. There is a little centre where you can have something to eat or buy Harvard merchandising products.
When you visit is finished i suggest you walk south by the river side right to the Boston University which is also very big and beautiful. The walk by the riverside is beautiful. !!

title: A nice respite from traffic
text: Cut off from the noise of the street, the Harvard Yard allowed us to walk diagonally through campus and view the students assembled in brightly colored chairs engaging in conversation or reading.

title: A nice stroll through Harvard Yard
text: On our way from the Red Line station we strolled through Harvard yard where many colored chairs were available for group sessions.  We went on to visit the Semitic and the Peabody museums as well as the museum of National History.

title: Hovering Harvard
text: We visited Boston via a cruise ship in mid-September and decided to take time to visit Harvard by the taking the T (metro) there.  The trip on the T was entertaining and an interest grabber for first timers in Boston - very easy to access and find your way about - also a lot less costly than taking a cruise ship excursion.  We loved walking through the grounds and while we didn't have time to take a guided tour we picked up on enough of the history to appreciate the surroundings.  The historic buildings emit an atmosphere of devotion to education and learning amid abounding stories of notable Americans.  We saw evidence of the Kennedys attendance here and a bit of nostalgia surrounding the era of the Kennedy family.  A stroll through the town-like streets was picturesque and low-key but enjoyable.  We visited the student run book store and bought a Harvard baseball hat for a relative - great little store.  Harvard is not a show-stopper but it is worthy of a visit just to say you've been there.

title: HAHVAHD
text: We went to get a T-shirt and it should have read, "My dad went to Harvard and all he got me was this crappy T-shirt." Yes, there are plenty of souvenir shops and tourists, but the tour provides an informative historical perspective. Easy access from Boston by cab or transit. Food and souvenirs are reasonably priced (you get a discount if you've taken the tour). Let's face it, most schools look like glorified prisons, but that doesn't mean you can't visit and have a good time.

title: Harvard Business School, best there is
text: We were there for a 45th reunion , very well attended, great campus, great lectures, great people! One of the best Bussiness Schools of this planet.

title: Interesting with a great student-led tour
text:
Took a $10 student-led tour of the Harvard yard and a couple of the neighbouring streets. Our (student) guide, Brie ("like the cheese") was anything but shy and probably born to do these kinds of tours; for more than an hour, she - despite a sour throat - constantly talked, explained, shared anecdotes and entertained our group. She had no written script and certainly wouldn't have needed one. She encouraged us to ask questions and did - as far as I can tell - a great job of answering them. All in all, this added a lot to our experience of Harvard and its history.

The Harvard yard itself (open and free of charge to visit) is rather impressing, with old buildings where lots of old presidents and other famous business people and celebrities have waked the corridors. Having been to Cambridge (England) and stayed in a college dorm room there for a short while, I was maybe not as hugely impressed with the Harvard campus as I otherwise would have been, yet it is indeed a place where it's well worth spending a few hours.

title: beautiful
text:
The campus is very beautiful. A lot of visitors. Widener Library is a must to visit, and it will be funny if you did some homework on the stories (some are fake) of this library. Drawback is the library is not open to public.

The Harvard statue is a statue of three lies. The inscriptions in the statue are all "fake". Do check this before visiting!

There are some restaurant outside the campus on Mass Ave. Chinese, italian, so on. The Harvard Coop store might be interesting to people who would like to take something about Harvard back home. Although they items are mostly overpriced, with a Harvard logo.

Harvard Museum of Natural History is my favorite site in the campus. There is an admission fee around $12 ($10 for students). It will take a whole day to take a through tour of it.

title: Incredible and Beautiful
text: We wandered around in awe as our daughter showed us her stomping grounds.  Simply said, this campus is astoundingly beautiful.  Leave yourself lots of time to explore the campus, it is huge.  And definitely take the student run tour.  They have a wealth of information at their fingertips.  Walk back in history as you learn how the school was started, and how Cambridge grew around this incredible institute of higher learning.  You won't be sorry you took the time to visit this incredible institution of higher learning.  If you have the opportunity, sit in on a class.  I feel like I learned more in one class at The Kennedy School than I did in four years of undergraduate work elsewhere.

title: underwhelmed
text: Im not sure what I was expecting.  Its overrun with tourists, we made a comment about feeling bad for the students.  The campus is average and the surrounding town was common.  Im glad we went and getting there on the T was easy but all in all there isn't much too it.  I wouldn't see the need to go back the next time Im in Boston

title: Great student-led tour
text: If you're interested and have the time, I highly recommend taking the student-led tour of Harvard Square.  These students have memorized a ton of history about the college and devote some of their personal time to share it with you.  Also, be sure to take advantage of the walking time with the student if you have kids interested in attending - they can provide good insight into what it's really like...but don't forget to tip them if you enjoyed it - they are college students after all...

title: Slightly underwhelmed
text: I was very much looking forward to this visit having studied at Cambridge University, UK and spent a considerable amount of time at Oxford also I was expecting similar visual splendour. Although the buildings were very impressive I disappointingly I felt a little underwhelmed particularly the grounds appeared somewhat tired. Perhaps a reflection of a true working University maybe? Nevertheless, a pleasure to wander around one of the premier institutes of academia in the world.

title: Great time
text: Had a great time touring the grounds. Be sure to cross the river and check out the business school and stadium. We were lucky enough to catch the rowing team as well.

title: A Must Do
text: If you are in the area, don't pass this up.  Wonderful history, beautiful buildings, enchanting students.

title: A great experience
text: Waking in this Historic place makes you enjoy your own college experience once more.  You will wish you were young again and able to be a part of this experience

title: Over scripted with very little real life information - Student Harver tour
text:
We did the student Havard tour while visiting Cambridge. It was $10 per person for a 1 hour guided tour through a small part of Harvard university as the university is very spread out.
Our guide was a student of Harvard. It was overall a disappointing tour. The guide stuck to her script (even closed her eyes when reciting it back to us) and the humour was really poor and much too scripted. The guide also was required to walk backwards which was very disconcerting and I felt that I had to watch out for her in case she would walk into something/someone.
We didn't actually get much of an insight into student harvard life nor were we told a lot about some of the more famous people who would have passed through the university.
I think the organisers of this tour should do a little bit of investigation into how other historical universities carry out their tours. My husband was on the Trinity College tour in Dublin a couple of weeks later and even though it was only 30 mins long he thought it was far superiour to the Harvard Tour and the guide was excellent.

title: Wish I was studying here!
text: Walk around the campus, through the squares and between the beautiful buildings - just a shame you can't go inside!

title: Great Campus
text: If only all uni campuses were like this! Great place to visit and the guided tours are very good. Lovely setting in quaint Cambridge in autumn/fall.

title: Must visit
text: Great university, great campus, great overall feel and the area that Harvard is at is worth spending a whole day. Go inside the chapel and make sure you speak to the university police they have the best tips about the place and nice secrets and stories to share.
