DO NOT touch the foot of Harvard, the statue....ask the police why

title: Simply the Best!
text: I had the best educational and social experience when I studied at Harvard. I was challenged and inspired whilst getting the best possible education and instruction. This is simply the best university in the world, and I am humbled to have studied there.

title: Feel a Historic Academe
text: We were able to go around this famous institution, and it gives a nostalgic feeling.  Parking around the university was a nightmare, however.   We were able to find a paid public parking, but the spaces were so small, that I wished that my car had a door in the back, like a SUV, so I can crawl out.  I am a very slender person, and I cannot hardly come out of the driver's seat. Likewise, pedestrians do not follow traffic lights and just cross the streets without looking.

title: Mediocre Campus
text: I have been to many college campuses and this one did not impress me.  We walked through the main quad area which was okay but nothing better than any other major university.  The buildings were classic and interesting but again, nothing that stands out from other similar institutions I have visited.  Harvard Square was pretty exciting and made the bike ride out there worth it but not by a lot.

title: Nice tour
text: We liked touring the #1 Award Winning University in the World.  It took us about an hour and 20 minutes to tour the buildings on the outside.  You are not really allowed to go inside any of the buildings.

title: Tours
text:
Make sure you take the student tour as it is one of the better ones.
The students tell you how it really is and give you incite you would not necessarily get. Walk the campus as it is drop dead gorgeous.

title: Harvard Yard - great experience!
text:
We took the Hahvahd tour during the day to explore the Harvard Yard and vicinity! Worth it every minute!
At night, we bought pizza at Otto's pizza and sat at the yard. The lawn chairs were inviting me and my family to enjoy a beautiful night under the starts and quietness of the yard. 
A magic moment as family where we felt isolated from the business of the streets outside of the yard and just relax!

title: Beautiful campus
text: A beautiful and lively campus. Be prepared to wait in line if you want to take a picture with Harvard's statue. Wish we had spent more time here to learn about the buildings - would definitely return to see more!

title: Beautiful Campus
text: An inviting studying environment with the most impressive bookstore that we have seen on campuses around the world.

title: Not Special
text: There's nothing particularly remarkable about Harvard Yard compared to any other college campus. It has grass, buildings, and statues. There honestly isn't much else to say about it. The grounds seem to be well-maintained, and there were plenty of places to sit either by yourself or with a group and enjoy an ice cream or good book.

title: So educational!
text: The student I had gave an excellent tour, I wish I could remember her name now... But she was very educated, explained a lot. I recommend doing the walking tour because you don't learn anything walking through the campus on your own.

title: Fun and informative Cambridge Historical Tour
text: The hour went too quickly. Walked through the Harvard campus with a costumed guide from Cambridge Historical Tours.  "Henrietta" had been an astronomer at Harvard (true story) in the late 1800's.  Started the tour at Harvard Square information booth across from the Coop.  Great stories about campus pranks e.g. Crimson vs. Lampoon.  Interesting info about John Harvard, Widener Library, some of the Harvard Yard Gates for example.   It was the highlight of our trip to Cambridge.

title: Place to visit in Cambridge
text: A totally new feeling compared to busy Boston. Nice place to hangout, have some good food and spend time enjoying history at Harvard.

title: Student walking tour
text: We bought the student walking tour. Justin, our guide was very nice and funny. He gave us lots of inside information. My college daughter loved it but my youngest daughter wasn't has excited. It would be nice if the tour included a visit of one residence or the librairy.

title: Busy area, despite the school break
text:
As part of our Harvard tour, the yard was a major part! Again this seems to be the central area for students as all the dorms are all around including the huge library. Depsite the fact that this was summer break, it was still fairly busy. There were several other tours coming and going, 
I can only begin to imagine how crowded this would be when school is in full swing.

title: Walking in Footsteps
text: Recently toured a small portion of Harvard. It wasn't until I looked at the map of Harvard that I realized how large this campus is and how it has expanded over the years. The history, alone is enough to justify a quick viewing. Our tour guide gave us a brief history about how the dormitory's are named, including the naming of the Library. The "3 Lies" of the statue of John Harvard. I would suggest getting a tour from someone. Just wandering around, is only part of the story, without an informed guide to tell you all the little things, you will miss out!

title: Loafing around here can't be beat
text: This is one of my favorite things to do: sit in Harvard Yard and surf the internet (free internet wifi) or just watch the people go by. Sometimes I catch a tour and listen. The speakers can be really funny.

title: Such a nice please to visit
text: The buildings, the lawns, the atmosphere, the history...a perfect package, certainly recommendable. Worth every minute we spent there.

title: Played on the field!
text: We showed up and walked around the campus and then the softball team practicing let us come onto the football field! Awesome experience!

title: Amazing campus and history.
text: Loved all the history and wish the library had been open. Also loved the local area..Harvard square. Great brunch places! Make sure to walk across the river to see the Harvard Business School and buy your attire from one of the student managed stores! Just ask. Wonderful area. Easy T Line access.

title: A Must Visit
text:
Harvard may be an almost untouchable university for most people as far as acceptances go, but who says you can't enjoy the gorgeous campus of the first university in the United States. 

We enjoyed an entire evening chilling and strolling around the oldest part of the university. You can sit around on the chairs, or have picnics on the lawn. 

My kids ran around and enjoyed some of the artifacts and statues that are placed all over the place. 

I'm a big fan of visiting Universities, and this one has been one of my favorite ones so far. And maybe the scholarly atmosphere rubbed off on my kids too.

title: What a place.
text: The moment you enter the Yard, you feel the history of the place. So many students have walked in this Yard the past century, and still do. Despite the tourists it remains a unique, calm place to visit and admire.

title: Student tour was great
text: We got a great tour from a Harvard student for only $10.  They are standing around at the train station exit with maps to give away for free even if you don't want to do the tour.  We had only a short time there so it was great to hear the history of Harvard with all the funny insider information that you aren't going to get by wandering around.  There are no buildings open to the public, so it is an outdoor tour, but still well worth it in my opinion.  I don't blame them for keeping their buildings closed to the public.  Make sure you hear the Conan O'Brien story!

title: Beautiful campus
text: After visiting the campus, I had to research WHY everyone wanted to touch the left foot of the John Harvard statue.  It was what I expected...just for luck!  I also discovered online that the statue was created by the same man that did the Lincoln memorial in Washington, DC.  And that the statue has 3 lies... Cool history to discover!

title: Lovely setting
text: Took a stroll round the pleasant yard, sat in the gardens a nice respite from the busy Harvard Square area. Lots of places to explore many of which seem to be open to the public.

title: Interesting.....
text: Great to see somewhere like this. Not what I expected. Kind of scattered all around town. Lines of people getting their picture taken with the John Harvard statue on the main campus.

title: Interesting if you're a Harvard alum
text: This was the first stop on a tour that took us to Lexington and Concord. Saying this will probably seem like a heinous crime to Harvard alums, but I think you really have to be one of them to get truly excited about this. But it does embody some history, so perhaps a peek at it is called for.

title: A great place to visit!
text: We visited harvard during the university holidays so there was a lot of tourists. It would have been better to go on a weekday or during univeraity times to see the students and experience the grounds at a less busy time. Incredible infastructure and grounds. Perfect on a sunny day. Taking a tour is definitely worthwhile to ensure you see everything and learn about the history. We took the 'free tours by foot' company where you decide the price of the tour. It was two houra long and very informative of both harvard and the surroundinf areas!

title: Beautiful!
text:
This place has to be seen. I wish I would stay longer because Harvard has beautiful grounds, very old churches.

This is a must when you visit Boston for the first time, lots of history there.

Will return sometime!

title: Save your time for something better
text:
As I am an academician, universities are always in my to do list. I was very excited about my Boston trip because I would be able to see Harvard, MIT and Boston University. Unfortunately, I spared two hours of my short trip to Harvard University and If I knew I could not enter any of the buildings (not even the library) I would not come to Harvard. 
If you want to see some old buildings, just walk through Boston downtown. It does not worth the long T trip. All buildings were locked, art museum was closed until Fall 2014, the library did not issue me a day pass because i did not bring a letter from my advisor (I am a PhD student and this is the most ridiculous practice I have ever seen. All researchers are welcome in my university's library, and I could enter all libraries across the country with my university ID but Harvard is an exception). 
Do you want to learn the history of the university? Read it. Buildings do not have informative signs, even the campus maps are rare.

title: Student tour
text: This was really enjoyable and a fun way to learn more about Harvard. Tours were picked up at the entrance to the T and the man at the desk was able to suggest a number of options, including tour guides in full dress. We only had an hour so didn't finish the tour - but was still good value at $10

title: Save some $- Take the free student tour!
text: As soon as you get off the subway in Cambridge hawkers approach you to take a $10 tour of Harvard University.  Take a few more steps to the Information Centre, where students offer free tours of the campus.  The history of the school is very interesting and the walk around the campus is lovely.  Students do a great job.  If you are in Cambridge, take an hour to take the tour.

title: Steeped in history
text: The entire experience of this university city is great. Whether strolling through the campus, being helped by the campus police, (most helpful guy). Lunching at The Charles in the courtyard .... Most delicious cranberry and nut bread.  All in striking of the main campus.  Of course one must rub the toe of John Harvard's statue.

title: Informative tour of Harvard Uninversity
text: This walking tour is free, sponsored by Harvard U, gives you a history of the place and points out the famous buildings on campus.

title: A must-see
text: Harvard University is the main attraction in Cambridge, and there is much more than John Harvard's statue and Harvard Yard: The stadium by Charles river, Charles river itself, Annenberg hall (which unfortunately tourists can't enter) and The Coop. Science Center, JFK school of Government and the Law School are also very beautiful.

title: A must see
text: Whether you take an organized (by students) tour or not, you'll certainly enjoy walks through the old buildings and yards, where the history really breathes on you all the time...

title: Probably better if you were going there
text: Harvard is clearly a must see when you are in the city.  There are tours given by students that are fun or you can do it alone.  The buildings are beautiful and the history of the university is pretty overwhelming.  Better to do it in the summer when there are fewer people.  Its not the quintessential campus as it is in the city.  Still, its pretty.

title: Absolutely  Beautiful
text: The campus is absolutely amazing!  It's much larger than one might think and there is so much history there.

title: A nice history and education tour
text: We follow the suggested itinerary from TripAdvisor to have a self-guided tour, it took us about 1.5 hrs. Several seating area around the campus, good for our tired foot. We were there when the summer school is on going, all the building are not accessible. Several good restaurant around the campus, and several street show near the T station.

title: Not worth the visit
text: I was a little disappointed - I thought it would be a beautiful campus, but it was not well maintained.

title: Free, cool shade and comfy chairs
text:
This was a fun surprise after a day of walking.  The colorful metal chairs come in three types, so, seek out the slant back lounger model--the other varieties are straight back no arms, and then there straight back with arms. 

 Match up with the footstools, and you are set for a Cambridge attraction.  There are no tickets, no lines, no rental fees.  Find your favorite expanse of shade, and view the world from this centuries seasoned perch.

title: Elegant, Scenic and Classic
text: For some reason, Harvard University reminds me of University of Dhaka (mostly 60s & 70s). Maybe because of the fact that it has been the center of admiration for such a long time. I found Harvard more welcoming than expected (in terms of visiting the campus). You can roam around the campus as long as you want. The only problem: most of the buildings didn't have names/tags. For first time visitors, it's little difficult to figure out.

title: Historic place
text: A lot history. Walk the campus. Fun looking at the place. Touch the toe of john Harvard.  Wish I did the student tour so I could have learned more.

title: IS SIMILAR TO OTHER UNIVERSITIES
text: We visited Harvard University during our trip to Boston with group. I liked the campus and the English style buildings of this University, especially the bibliotheq with the Greek architecture like Parthenon. The point visiting a university is not to know it's history, as is easy to get it in internet, but to see all the atmosphere of the whole place. Really Norfolk University at Virginia, where my children are graduated, has nothing less than Harvard, either buildings, gardens, very big bibliotheq and even a school for the kids of students that have no where to leave them during studing at University. I believe that Harvard University is like an attraction at Cambridge after  people that were graduated, became famous.

title: Just for the name! - Nothing else is special
text:
I visited this place only for the reputation it had. As a tourist, it was nothing so great. Didn't get into the museum though. Unless, getting here gives you some inspiration or a satisfaction, I wouldn't recommend this place. 

It is just another university campus - except for the great Harvard brand.. So if you have better things to do, please go ahead.. I wouldn't go again if I get a chance to..

There are some harvard tours too. I don't think it is worth spending on them, unless you badly want to see it..

title: Atmosphere
text: Walked around the campus.  Lots of tourists & tours.  Beautiful day to be outside.  Pleasant campus vibe.

title: We got to to to the gift shop.
text: We should have either took a taxi or booked a tour. When got there the only parking available was meter parking that would only let you pay for an hour. We still got to walk around for a little while and go to the gift shop. I have worn my Harvard shirt at least once a week ever since.

title: Bring your kids and/or grandkids
text: I graduated from this fine institution many years ago and have never regretted it. Worth a visit, both for the splendid university it is and also as an unforgettable piece of American history and important incubator for its future talent. Bring the youngsters along - they all need something to aspire to.

title: Hallowed Halls
text: What abeautiful historic establishment.  Widner Library is well worth a visit.  The historic tour was informative and worthwhile providing both relevant facts and some funny and quaint facts

title: Beautiful Campus
text: If you are near Cambridge, you must see the university. We walked from our hotel as I'm sure parking would be impossible. Lots of historic buildings to see and enjoy the beauty of the campus in the city.

title: college
text: I travelled by train to the University and got some excellent pictures there. Very nice area and very historic. I recommend checking it out if you are in the Boston area.

title: Student Walking Tour of Harvard University 5/6/2013- A great half day activity.
text:
Student Walking Tour of Harvard University 5/6/2013

A great half day activity that doesn't break the bank. Take the 15-20 minute subway trip out to Cambridge and take the Student lead tour through Harvard University. The cost of the trip is $10.00 and money well spent. The tour company is run by Harvard University students and all the proceeds go back to the students. The tour start is located at the main exit  from Cambridge Subway. You will be meet by a person who will direct you to a small newspaper stand where you pay your money and get your ticket.  You then take your ticket back to the person who then gives you a sticker. It is a little round about but it works.

Our tour guide was a third student who was 5 foot and 1 inch tall named Brett (This is how he introduced himself). He was a pocket rocket, he was very enthusiastic about showing the group around, telling great stories of the going on's of the students, pointing out where famous graduates or 'non graduates' lived and studied and informing the group of the history of America's oldest university. The tour is two hours long and finishes at a park just outside the university walls. There is a great cafe located here for lunch and just around the corner is the subway for the trip back to Boston. My wife and I enjoyed it no end.  We explored the campus further after the tour and their Business College campus were beautiful with well manicured gardens!

title: Informative tour
text: We went on the free student led tour on a weekday morning with a group of about 30 people. The student guide was friendly and informative and answered guest questions. She made the history of the buildings come alive and included some of her personal experiences as she talked about her major, which dorms she lived in, etc.

title: Great small university town!
text: The fact that the university is pretty much integrated into the town gives it a terrific 'Oxford/ Cambridge' feel.

title: Take the Hahvahd tour!! So funny!!
text: I had a great time. When we got out of the train, students were right at the exit to get a new group of travellers. Super easy, no need for booking. The students giving the tour were so funny. We laughed, learned, walked around. You give the amount you want at the end of tour.

title: Student Led Tours
text: There are student led tours for free of the campus. It gives you background that walking around the campus would not give you. Stories about how freshman are picked for their upperclassmen house and what happened the morning after the library burned down. When you get off the subway there is an information booth that will point you to where the free tours are. They also sell a great map for 25 cents. The bookstore The Coop is a good place to buy a souvenir. L. A. Burdick is a chocolate shop right by Harvard. Expensive but nice. Your can walk to Brattle Street nearby and take a tour of Longfellow's house. It is an amazing tour and worth the 15 minute walk from the campus.

title: Amazing
text: This campus is stunning,  its a beautiful array of historical buildings.  Take the student led tour on campus it's free and very informative.  The whole community is gorgeous! Breath of fresh air from the big city of Boston.  Right off the T subway.

title: The cradle of American Liberal Arts Education!
text: England has Oxbridge, the US  has Harvard! Lovely setting in the very middle of Cambridge. Visit both the Old and the New Yard, Memorial Church, Widener Library (the second largest library in the US after the Library of Congress), walk where so many past Presidents, famous economists, scientists, psychologists, experts have done before!

title: I want to be an undergrad
text: The admissions tour along with a guided tour made me wish I could re-do my undergrad years, but do it at Harvard.  I now understand the remarkable draw of the residential college system and the incredible number of activities available to the students.  It is in a great location with mass transit readily available.  A must see when in Cambridge!!

title: Lots of amazing buildings
text:
The campus is one great building after another. Students are giving out free maps in the main square. You can join a student tour with them at 10 dollars. I decided to stroll around on my own.
Easy to get to with the T.

title: Can't miss Harvard's campus
text: Graduation had just take place and they were getting ready for another one. Slipped in to take a picture with the famous statue. Grounds are beautiful and everyone allowed the visitors to enjoy what they get to see daily. The entire area is very friendly and there are lots of pick up gifts right outside. A map of the campus is available and there's the museum if you have time to visit.

title: Don't Park your Car in Harvard Yard, take the T
text: You have to go and walk the Harvard Yard.  it is a short T ride and when you get off the T Stop you are there.  So it is easy and something you should do.  there are also some great places around there as well.

title: 2013 Commencement
text: the 2013 Commencement is a great joy for all!, With Oprah and fellows its always a great tradition to continue threw the years. Harvard has so much to offer, and so much to give not only to the students but to the community at hand. Harvard is and always will be the great Cambridge Institution where people come to learn from great minds.

title: Free campus tours are great
text: I have toured Harvard Campus with three different students and each time I have learned a different aspect of Harvard's history and present day personality. The university is rich with stories.

title: Map for money!
text: In general i enjoyed the trip to Harvard. However i find it rediculous that the information center charge 2 dollars for a map of the campus. And it is the only option. Stingy much?

title: Busy location
text: We found our visit to Harvard interesting, but it was extremely busy. We encountered many tourist groups (30+ people) on our wander around the grounds, which wasn't a problem but you need to be patient for photo opportunities, especially around the John Harvard statue.  Glad we visited - but not a great deal for the kids to do.

title: Classic ivy league Campus
text: From the exterior setting (a quiet oasis within bustling Harvard Square) to the stately old buildings, the campus is definitely somewhere that everyone living or visiting Boston should stop by.

title: a great university
text: Because as far as I know so many great  minds, presidents, bigwigs, celebrities, political people and great lawyers of the country and known around the world studied there. The education cost is expensive and only those who can really afford can study there, of course even scholars need to have their own personal  expense, too. When we entered the grounds, I already felt its greatness and now it is still one of the great universities around the world, that even royal people felt honored to study and graduate there. the grounds are really wide and it took sometime for us to finish the walk, and to take pictures of the different areas. It also took a while to pose in front of the statue of the founder of the university. The trip was really worth it!

title: History, grandeur
text: Great for a visit (and education - i have heard...). Would definitely take a tour. awesome place to see one of the oldest institutions of learning (in America).

title: Take The Tour
text: We visited Harvard twice on our vacation. The first time we walked through on the way to the Peabody Museum but the second time we took the 1 hr tour. It was led by one of the students who was very entertaining. Brent, Bret, Brad (sorry I can't remember his name) gave us some very interesting information on the history and lore of Harvard. Well worth the $10.

title: A bit of history - definitely go into the church
text: If you're a tourist in Boston, Harvard University is definitely worth a visit even if it's just to walk around the square to take the history in. It's a good way from the centre of Boston but easily accessible by T line or bus.  We were there when it was pouring with rain so ran for shelter into the church.  This turned out to be a major result as it was stunning and a real example of Boston's historical past. We were doubly lucky in that we had it all to ourselves and then a gentleman started to play the wonderful organ.  It was like a wonderful oasis from the weather and the traffic.

title: Nothing more than a yard
text: It's just a yard. really. and it's not like you could even picnic on it.  No reason to visit it unless you plan on visiting Harvard itself.  Then you might as well stroll across it because you can get a vibe for the students and faculty or even take a tour.

title: Fun Walk
text: Our family walked around the campus while in Cambridge to cheer our son in the Boston Marathon.  Amazing architecture, lovely grounds and tons of history.  A pleasant afternoon

title: Been there got the tee-shirt!
text: It is worth a visit primarily because it is so famous throughout the world. It is good to see what it is all about and has some pretty (if slightly plain) buildings. It certainly is no where near as pretty as the likes of Cambridge and Oxford in the UK. We visited the Natural History Museum which was quite good and you get access to the Peabody museum included. Didn't seem too many (food & drinks) facilties for non students but it was nice to meander around and observe. We enjoyed the John Harvard Statue where local legend has it if you touch his left foot then your IQ will increase; there may be something in this as my wife did and over the next couple of days she did have a couple of very insightful moments!!

title: Didn't do much for me
text: Our son was cross admitted to Yale and Harvard. We visited Yale 1st and Harvard just couldn't live up to the beauty. The people there also lacked the warm and welcoming attitude that seemed to ooze from the folks at Yale. Guess which college he will be attending in the fall???

title: Of course you have to see it
text: Would have been nice if there were more on campus for visiting parents to do, like even an open coffee shop.  The  museum is great but there really wasn't any place to duck in and relax.

title: Day trip
text: Went to Cambridge to see what Harvard was all about. Did not go on any organised tours. Spent half a day around the campus. Lots of little pubs and restaurants. There is Harvard Shirt store on Mass  ave, that have all the choices, and prices are a lot less than in a souvenirs stores in Boston.

title: Great and informative experience!
text: I went on one of the free tours given by Harvard students and was amazed by their knowledge and understanding of the history and present day use of the University.  The information jam packed into an hour was amazing and the personal antedotes made the experience more valuable.

title: You should visit when students are not on a break
text: Harvard yard is very strange, when students are on a break.  So, try to schedule your visit when the yard is full of students, going to the libraries or running to the next class. Say "hello" to John Harvard, walk the steps of Widener's library. You can visit it too!  Walk into the Emerson hall, which houses the Philosophy department. Walk out of the yard, and visit the Art museum (from Harvard Square entrance, across the yard)  If you have a full day, see if there is an interesting film at Harvard Film Archives (Carpetner Center, practically next to the Art Museum). If you have more than 1 day for a visit, check out Science center, just across the Harvard Yard and many Harvard Museums.

title: READ BEFORE YOU GO :)
text: I am amazed to see some of the reviews. I do not know what people might expect from a university, particularly such a big one, not to mention the oldest :)  Walk the Harvard yard, go to the museum of your interest - Harvard has many.  Visit the Business School area, to feel the difference :) Attend one of the concerts or a theater performance. Take a walk along Charles, and see the Harvard residential housing.  Before you go, visit the Harvard information web site, or the Information Center in Cambridge

title: Not only historical and beautiful, but a real crossroads.
text: The storied halls of Harvard attract not only students and prospective students, but also tourists from all over the world. They, and the world-class scholars, speakers, and other celebrities constantly passing through, give this stately old quadrangle the excited feel of an axis mundi. You are at the center of the academic world here, and you can feel it in the air. What's more, the Yard is completely open and simple to access — just walk in. Unlike the colleges at Yale or Oxford, you are welcome to stroll through and soak in the heady atmosphere. Don't forget to rub John Harvard's left foot for good luck, peek into Memorial Church, and gaze at the massive façade of Widener Library in the New Yard!

title: A great mix of people
text: Harvard yard is a great way to go from one side of Cambridge from the common to Kirkland Street. You always see lots of students, parents, visitors and folks that want to feel the Harvard spirit. Don't forget to rug John Harvard's toe for good luck.

title: Great tour of Harvard Univ from Harvard SQ
text: I was in Boston last week end and saw the volunteers from the Student organization talking about the tour. I love old architecture so I signed up for it. It was fun, funny, well researched and it was special since the students are your guide. You get the insiders view. The tour takes you to the famous yard, walks around the yard and brings you near the book store where you can get souvenir or pay the fees of ten dollars. Its pretty good for the price. Your guide will tell you all the history and fun facts about the campus. Its for an hour and I would recommend it for wanna be Bostonians or Harvardians!

title: a place to visit in Boston
text: Since we are already in Boston, we decided to see Harvard University Campus, nothing much to do there except to go around the campus, take a look at the buildings, have a picture taken on the statue of John Harvard. It's worth seeing though and I'm glad we did went there.

title: Not entertaining...
text:
If you are bored and want to get more bored then this is the right place to visit. 
I was surprised how badly they welcome guests in this place because I was expecting visitors center when I arrived but instead they wander around the area like headless chickens.

title: A Must See!
text:
Recently visited Harvard and took the student led tour.  Our guide was Alexis who was fantastic, knowledgable and full of enthusiasm which really made the tour worthwhile.  The tour lasts for an hour and costs $10 donation per person or $20 per family up to 5 people.

A definite must do for any visitor and well done Alexis!!

title: trademark tour!
text: departs from info booth at harvard square, you visit campus guided by harvard senior students, not only you learn interesting facts about the university they also share funny anecdotes

title: Feeling history
text: I recently moved back to the Boston area and this time on the far banks of the Charles in Cambridge in Huron Village and walking around my new neighborhood took me to Harvard Yard. The Yard has that mystic and sense of privilege few Americas will ever partake. Especially in this time of shifting morality and values, walking through Harvard embudes one with an understanding of the virtues of intellectual endeavor.

title: Beautiful campus, great free tour.
text: We went to Harvard and took the free university tour that is offered by students. It was very interesting to learn all the history of the school and funny facts about all the buildings, etc. Our tour guide was very good and also told us about her life as a student, which I found very interesting. Made it more real, plus you got an insight into what being a student at Harvard is like!

title: Take the tour!
text: The Historical ($) or the General admissions (FREE) tour are great! This is History, and it is very interesting, The buildings and architecture are incredible. Spend the day! Plenty of restaurants and cafes within and around the campus.

title: Great campus tour; fab staff!!
text: Here on a college visit with my daughter.  It's #1 on her list.  Great tour, very informative & super staff!  Thanks for an awesome visit.  Keeping fingers crossed at application time!  ;). Park in a public lot or watch street signs very closely!  We were warned, but others were not so lucky.  A 10 car length stretch of road could have 3 different parking restriction signs....read the signs carefully!!  We had a nice lunch at Panera across the street & met students (all wonderful) which added to some of our tour questions & hearing things first hand.  A classic & classy college!

title: A pleasant wander on a sunny day
text: I have visited Harvard University on several occasions, the first time because  it was the setting for a novel I enjoyed. Since then it has become a semi-regular haunt, and I have visited several of the buildings as well as wandering the campus. Buildings are widely located so a rainy day is not conducive to a pleasant visit. However, if in Cambridge, it is a must.

title: Beautiful old campus!
text: I enjoyed the self-guided walking tour (pick up a brochure in a nearby info center).  I also enjoyed going into the Houghton Library with rare books and manuscripts.  It is a relaxing  walk and the tour takes about 1 hour, with good cafes nearby.  Massachusetts Hall is the 2nd oldest academic building still in use in the U.S.

title: Seminar at the Grad School of Education
text: Had an excellent experience at a professional seminar at the Harvard Graduate School of Education. Mostly held in Larsen Hall and Gutman Library, the conference was well-organized, food was good, snacks were abundant, and space was comfortable. What a great experience!

title: a must for any Boston trip
text: no trip to Boston would be complete without a walk round this historical place, eight US presidents have graduated from here

title: Great tour
text: My friend and I took a tour in March of 2007. We had a great time. We went to the info center to take one. We went into a couple of buildings and got loads of information. The tour was free and the student tour guide was great. It was freezing outside when we did it but she kept us moving so we wouldn't feel the cold.

title: Beautiful
text: We were in the area and knew we had to stop at Harvard (just to say we were there)!  It was pretty easy parking but we did go right away in the morning.  We walked around Harvard yard which is pretty impressive to see.  We did not go into any buildings but we did take some photos and walked around.  I'd recommend a stop if you're in the area and have some time.  Helpful tip - view the map of campus on your cellphone to help with driving in the area and walking around. It helped a lot!

title: Pretty amazing.
text: Don't miss the Sackler Museum. It's small, but it's got an excellent collection, and shouldn't be overlooked if you're in Cambridge. There are tours, both official and unofficial, of Harvard. And restaurants abound. To walk through The Yard is a treat on a Sunday morning, especially since the students are all still asleep in their dorms!

title: Do the student-led walking tour! A must.
text: You can find info about student-led tours on the Harvard website. I am so glad we chose to do this tour because A: It's free and B: It's very informative, and a great way to learn about the school's history. Our tour guide was a senior at the school and very humorous and knowledgeable. What would have been a few minute walk around the school by ourselves wondering what things are turned into an hour of entertainment and information with the tour guide. Highly recommend!

title: Awesome experience, but I  wish I could enter more buildings
text: I have to admit the aura the surrounds Harvard lives up to it's reputation. It's easy to get  via the T, just jump on the outbound Red line.  We went a bit too late to get a tour so we walked round the Campus.We started off at the Harvard Business school which is on the Other side of the Charles River (approx 5min from the main campus) and then walked to the Main Campus. For the most part the buildings are of old architecture and definitely give that prestigious vibe. There is a photo opportunity around each corner. I'd say the one downside is you are not able to enter most buildings. We did enter the Law library after asking and I have to say it was breathtaking. I would definitely recommend trying to get into one of the libraries its totally worth it. Overall Harvard is an amazing place. You can make an afternoon of it by grabbing food at Harvard Square.

title: Nostalgia Harvard University
text: We wanted to see with our own eyes the university as famous! Beautiful nostalgic place. It's worth a visit and a full stop is required. It is to see at least once in his life, other than in the movies. Guided tours are offered by students. Do not forget to take a picture with John Harvard ... but most people on the site!!! We can walk free on the site, but we can not entry in building. No toilet!

title: Historic home for undergraduate freshmen
text: The Yard is actually home-away-from-home for most of Harvard's freshmen class.  Relax under the shady trees or join a free walking tour (go to info center in the Holoyoke center) to really learn about the history, people, landmarks.

title: Iconic University
text:
We brought our two sons to Harvard University last summer when we visited Boston to show them the most popular university in the US and in the world. I dont really know whether they will be inspired to study enough to gain entry to this university but just seeing this place is worth the trip.

Its such a huge campus that you would need at least a day to really get acquianted with the area.

title: Nice Place to Walk Around
text: If you are in the area, and you are bored, definitely take some time out of your day to check this out. Harvard University is known world-wide and getting to say that you stepped on some of their land is pretty special if you are visiting internationally. The actual area is quite large, but there is plenty of information available to help you get your way around easily. Lots of history is in the area and there are some pretty awesome spots to get some pictures. Another great thing is that it's right beside MIT, so you can visit both in one day. Visit if you have time!

title: visit the real Harvard --free official tour
text: For an authentic, free tour lead by current Harvard student ambassadors, go to the info center located in the Holoyoke Arcade on Mass Ave. near Harvard Square.  You'll get a historic and exciting tour--the best way to see what Harvard really is!  Offered Monday through Saturday at 10, noon, and 2 but call or check online for more info.

title: Amazing institution
text: Beautiful campus with knowledgeable student tour guides.  A must do activity if you are interested in attending.

title: Very impressive
text: Nice area, nice University, but very exclusive. Just visited Harvard on an Open Day, enjoyed the visit even though it was extremely cold and very windy!

title: Bottom line
text: Getting into Harvard is overrated.  The rigor of a Harvard education is also overrated, especially now that we know that cheating is a big problem.  The endowment is the biggest in the nation, and much of the money is being used to encroach upon a lower middle class Boston area known as Alston.  Many graduates become wealthy lawyers, doctors, and investment bankers.  No doubt Harvard students and professors have contributed much to this great country and the university is the elite of the elite.  Just ask anybody there.

title: Graduate Party
text: Went for my son's graduation. This place is special and just being in the Yard is cool for this Okie. More history than I can stand and more Japanese camera toting tourists than you can imagine. Very cool. Go.

title: Beautiful place
text:
I heard the history talked by the campus tour guides. They were really passionate, and one has a half Chinese pedigree. After the tour, they brought us the lunch taking under the trees and on the grass.
Visiting date was in July 2009.

title: Dream University
text:
It is fantastic. It is my dream uni, though I know I have no chance to be a member of it. So, I bought some souvenir in its old tranditional souvenir shop. I recommend the travellers should join the HAVAD (something like that) campus tour. 
Visiting date was in July 2009.

title: Harvard
text: Well if your in Cambridge MA, you will probably go here! Its beautiful but not as charming as the Cambridge UK. As for the usefully tips - its not to hard to find a car parking, and restaurants are ok around the uni.

title: Must See!
text: Visiting Harvard was like finally "at Harvard". Ivy League and all the hype, it was good to finally see the school that produces some of the world's finest minds. With its rich history and cultures, it was obvious that Harvard is half what it is as a result of preserved cultures and traditions. It was an impressive outing!

title: Free tour
text: Got a free tour from one of the Students. Well worth spending the time to hear the history of the university.

title: I've Been To Harvard :0)
text: Well I visited the Campus :0) Another must visit for a trip to Boston is Harvard.  Well known across the world and the subject of many a film.  The campus is well worth a walk around, and taking a few pictures.

title: Tour of Harvard
text: This is a must do when in Boston, tour is conducted by students it's so informative, funny & you really get a great feeling for college life past and present!

title: Good but closed for holidays
text:
So awesome to stand in Harvard Yard...history and you could almost hear great minds churning. 
Luckily, we got on a tour by a graduate as regular tours re not happening due to holidays (despite tourists???). 
Shops in area are fun for browsing...especially if you like bookstores.

title: IT'S HARVARD FOR GOD'S SAKE
text: The only reason this place gets 4 stars is because the author went to another IVY School and therer is a matter of schoold pride at stake here. Putting that aside, thi is a fabulous place to visit (or go to school at) and the various museums and lectures that are presented are without compare.

title: Harvard University
text: I remember the Harvard of  1981 when I first came to the area and all of the things that were done differently than are done today.  The Business school and Harvard Real Estate have essentially driven the interesting stores, bars, restaurants, night clubs and booksellers out of the area and replaced them with banks.   While some of it is left  and it is still interesting it is a shadow of what it was.

title: achivement galore !!!
text: Now this is something which you can only...visit and feel.. there are no review worth which can compel you to come and visit here.. you have to come with call in your heart. Harvard epitomizes...the craving of knowledge and its distribution..you see the world congregate here to worship the alter of knowledge. MUST SEE AND EXPERIENCING THE  EUPHORIA

title: Harvard University
text: I took the train to Harvard and I was amazed at the structure of the buildings, the size of the campus. The entire campus itself is very different that what I had imagine; it was very pleasant sight...

title: Hard to beat Harvard
text: I had always wanted to visit Harvard and it lived up to my expectations. We took the number 1 bus from the city which dropped us at the Visitors Centre right across from Harvard Yard. We took a 10am free tour hosted by one of the second year students. The guide had an extensive knowledge of the campus its history and fun facts like where Matt Damon lived when he was a student. The guide succeeded in making us very envious of her being a student. The tour was quite structured and while we did go inside one of the building a downside was the lack of access to most buildings which are for students only. The old buildings are magnificent and there are ample photo opportunites but the best part was the guide herself who was fantastic and answered many questions my wife and I had on education in the USA and how it differs from our educational experiences in Australia. Highly recommended.

title: walking around cambridge boston
text: lovely location to walk around didnt go in though. Havard square lovely shops and cafes. Gorgeous wooden new england houses lined the streets, about a 25 mins walk from our hotel.

title: John Harvard
text: I took my granddaughter to rub John Harvard's foot for good luck. A great place to visit because it's a peaceful historic place with easy access to the T and Harvard square. Harvard square is also a great place to visit.

title: Nice campus
text: This was my first glimpse at an American Ivy League about 10 years ago.  It's a pretty campus, and certainly has an air of prestige, but I'm not sure if it's all cracked up to what people say it is.  I have since visited other non-Ivy league schools such as Stanford and I much prefer the laid back country club style atmosphere I experienced there.  Less snobbery and more relaxed!

title: Actually-Harvard Square--The Campus mini-city
text: Really safe atmosphere for night life. College age as well as adult attractions. My personal favorite was the House of Blues. As this is geared toward the college student, drink specials are common. Realy good live entertainment on most nites and a really friendly atmosphere.

title: Definitely worth the trip
text: We have always wanted to come to see Harvard. It was everything we.expeted and more. We joined a free tour which runs for an hour at 10.30am and maybe 12.30pm, there is possibly another after that also from the intonation desk just across from the campus. Our guide was fantastic and very knowledgeable and was able to answer all our questions. We got to see the uni and the squirrels. The only down side is that we are unable to go into the buildings. Uh are also able to purchase Harvard memorabilia from the store, it's well priced. It's a great tour and history I defiantly recommend it.

title: Absolutely beautiful!
text: One of the highlights of our recent trip to Boston was our visit to Harvard University.  It was so beautiful!  We decided to take a last minute tour with one of the costumed guides standing in the Square. It cost $12 each. The young lady who was our guide provided so many interesting facts about Harvard and the history of the surrounding area.  If you plan to visit Boston, Harvard is a must see!

title: graet university
text:
harvard university is the best university in the world.
bulidings in this uinversity are very old and people visit the buldings easy,
exclusivly kennedy school is the best faculity . i saw this

title: Beautiful Campus
text: Very interesting and fun to visit such a storied campus.  Harvard was started in 1636 so it is the old institution of higher learning in the United States.

title: Hah Hah Hahvahd
text: We went on one of the Hahvahd funny tours led by a student.......Lorenzo.  Lorenzo kept the tour upbeat and contemporary whilst also being very knowledgable about the University's history.   The tour was only $10 paid at the end.  It was worth every cent.

title: Worth the trip
text: Definitely worth the trip as its steeped in history.  Some folks whith different expectations might be disappointed but keepng it in context it is welll worth an hour or so of your time.

title: Nice peaceful setting that makes you feel smarter just being there.
text: On our visit to Cambridge we came upon Harvard Yard. I must have heard of it before,as the name resonates with me. A large green courtyard with might maple trees surrounded by halls of knowledge. There the statue of John Harvard watches in repose as small flocks gather to reflect...Or eat lunch,nap or consult there personal electronic devices. Here on the green are arranged some simple chairs that are quite comfortable to sit in and observe from. Somehow I felt like a scholar as I sat and took it all in. Sun streamed through the trees dressed in there full autumn flame and warmed the hearts of all who took pause...there upon the yard.

title: Intellectual capital of the US
text: The oldest University in America. Walk through the Yard, look at the buildings, sense the history. Lots of public art on display - sculpture, architecture.

title: Nice historic campus
text: As a visitor to Boston/Cambridge it is worthwhile to take one of the walking tours of Harvard University. We took an unofficial tour that was run by a group of Harvard students (its free, but tips are suggested). The students gave us a very interesting overview of the campus and the history of the university buildings as well as several funny incidents along the way. If you cannot take the tour, a simple walk through the campus is nice to get a feel of the institution. Afterwards a walk through Harvard Square, and a visit to the Harvard Coop is a must.

title: Definitely worth a visit
text: For a tourist spending just a short time here, it is worthwhile to go on one of the free tours conducted by students. We had a very bad weather yet the young lady leading the tour managed to keep us all interested. Afterwards, we went to the Carpenter Center for Visual Arts - the only building in the US designed by Le Corbusier.

title: Beautiful place
text: It seems that you are in some american movie when you visit Harvard. Beautiful place with a lot of green and great landscape. After visiting the university you can across the street and drink a coffee in starbucks or walk in harvard square and buy some gifts.

title: The best university in the world
text: If you were a kid accepted to Harvard, you'd be crazy not to go. The cream of the crop for a reason...excellent faculty, staff and students...academic opportunities abound. Stellar alumni. Simply the best.

title: Big and beautiful
text: I love the law school building in Harvard university and the space with trees and some squirrel running around.  The science building were great for the students to sit around and discuss ideas.  The only thing that I found was that it was loads of concrete compared to some of the older building (I love the older buildings).  The kids will be lucky to have a place like this to study for sure and it was really pretty for the visitor just walk about the campus to admire the few buildings.  :)

title: Its Hardvard
text: Another must see in Boston.  You will recgonize this from many many different movies.  You must go and at least get a picture taken there.  Then you can walk around Harvard :)

title: A few things to do here
text: Some people may want to see Harvard just to get an idea of what a great university looks like, but there really isn't much to do in Harvard itself.  There are a few museums operated by the university (reviewed separately), but visitors mostly just walk through the courtyards.  The surrounding shopping and dining area is fun, however, and, for some, it's exciting just to be in an atmosphere of people who are dedicated to learning.

title: 50th Reunion Harvard Law School
text: The reunion was well organized, and featured excellent programs put on by alumni of the Class of 1962.  All meals on the law school campus.

title: The most famous university in the world
text: Harvard square is always a bit hectic, but the tour is worth it.  There are historic tours and campus tours - choose the historic tour.  So many brilliant folks graced these grounds its amazing to learn about it!

title: Great tour by Harvard Students
text: This hour long tour is guided by Harvard University students, at a small suggested cost of $10 per person.  The student lead us around a large section of the University highlighting important, well known buildings and structures, giving us great inside information at the same time.  Who knew that Al Gore & Tommy Lee Jones shared a room in their freshmen year, & are still great friends today? We thoroughly enjoyed the tour & were left hungry for more information.  Just go to the information booth in Harvard Square & spend a wonderful hour in an iconic institution.

title: Footy
text: We went to a Harvard Holy Cross football game in the rain and soaked in the best of the Crimson's fighting spirit.  The stadium is colloseumesque and very picturesque.  The food attendants did not mind explaining the nuances of American food.  (Not exactly a 4 n' 20).

title: 376 Years Old University
text:
My first visit to Harvard University was over 20 years ago. My first impression was that the campus had some very old buildings, and some of them were closed due to lack of maintenance. It might be there was not enough funding at the time. Recently, I revisited Harvard University, and it completely changed my opinion. I am glad that we made the right decision to learn more about this renowned and historical school. We took the subway to Harvard Square Station and walked to Harvard Information Center in the Holyoke Center Arcade. This was a good start because they offer a free tour of the Harvard Yard, which is led by a senior student. Normally, it has 3 scheduled guided tours (10 am, 12 pm and 2 pm) everyday. It is suggested to check the schedule before you go because it might not have the tours due to various reasons. It is a one-hour walking tour, and it covers most of the campus and its history. You do not need to make a reservation, but sometimes you might need to wait for the next available tour. If you prefer self-guided walking tour, you can visit their mobile tour website.

Harvard University is an American private Ivy League research university which celebrated its 376th anniversary in 2012. It is the oldest institution of higher education in the United States. There are many historic buildings in Harvard Yard. The high Victorian Gothic style Memorial Hall is one of the iconic buildings on the campus. It was built in 1870s to honor the Harvard graduates who fought for the Union in the American Civil War. Today, the Sanders Theatre is a lecture and concert hall, and the Annenberg Hall is used as the dining hall for the freshmen. The interior of Memorial Hall is a must see, and you might need to wait in line because it is the most impressive place on the campus. Another interesting location you can’t miss is the John Harvard statue and its “Statue of the Three Lies”. You can easily see his shining shoe because Harvard students and tourists believe rubbing the shoe will bring you luck.

I thought there must have been many directors who use the Harvard campus in their movies. However, I was wrong. Because the movie staff of The Love Story (1970) caused damage to the Harvard campus, the university administration refused most subsequent requests for filming on Harvard.

title: Great visit
text: It is awesome to visit the campus since it is such a premier institution in America.  Wonderful to know where the many brains are educated in this great institution.

title: The best
text: The museums are some of the best in the country.  Harvard Yard is quite historic and beautiful.  Harvard Square has a unique buzz.

title: Lay in the grass, take in the scenese
text: Walking around Harvard Yard is very peaceful. You don't feel like you're just outside the city when surrounded by the beautiful architecture of Harvard's campus. The lawns are all well manicured, and you can either just plop down in the grass, or they do have some metal chairs/benches scattered around to sit on. Lovely place to come and escape reality.

title: It is Harvard after all...
text: Lots of history, great stories, beautiful buildings this is a must see stop in Cambridge. Lots of options for the usual food, drink and clothing but many unique to Harvard

title: Best part of Cambridge, MA
text: I love strolling around Harvard Yard.  There are always tours passing through so just keep your ears open and you'll get a quick history lesson on John Harvard and all the famous people who have gone to Harvard.  There are hidden cafes in the yarrd and it's fun to just sit and people watch, I lucked into a llive perfomance by a singer with a guitar who was just passing through on his way to the pit (near the subway entrance where a lot of live performances are given)

title: knowledgable  tour guides
text: Yedam i hope I am spelling it right was awesome and a litttle girl from the west coast who had so much energy to share.  Of course, we did the bow, and yes we know about the chilling night events,truly we know have a better understanding  of life at Harvard. A free will donation at the end made it all good. I think eveyone should visit this place

title: A great place to hang out.
text: On warm days, there are tons of people sitting in the yard, chatting or reading. It's nice that the university provides chairs and foot stools, so you'll likely have a place to sit down. Great atmosphere.

title: Beautiful
text: Just a short way out of the city of Boston is this beacon of learning. The grounds are superb and the interiors of the buildings are lovely.

title: Student Free guided tour of Harvard.
text: You really should make time, a couple of hours to enjoy this place. Lilley was beginning her last year of study there. She took the group around for a hour or so giving us the history of the Uni and an insight of what it is like being a student there. My thanks to her.

title: good free tour
text: Find the visitor information centre and go on one of the hour long free tours led by a Harvard student - very engaging!

title: Absolutely beautiful & stores nearby
text: If you have the spare time while in Boston or Cambridge going to Harvard is a good thing to add to your list. The buildings are beautiful and Harvard Square, the nearby shopping area, is a great place to roam around on a good weather day (all outdoors). Highly recommended from a new Boston local. :)

title: So much excitement!
text: I loved just walking through Harvard Yard and watching all of the students! So much excitement and activity! I always feel so comfortable there and its nice to grab a snack in the Science Center.

title: Quirky tours for visiting parents et al
text: I thought the tour was great.  I especially like the bits about pranks, e.g., the stories of Harvard versus the city of Cambridge and the year a student (I shall not name him here to spoil the fun) who pitted two police forces (Harvard v. Cambridge) against each other one year.

title: I live near here and really love it
text: There is always something to see in the Yard, even if it is just the buildings, the configuration and the trees.  However, the visitors are great to see, the tours are fun to hear and the mix of faculty, students, visitors, parents and locals is great fun.  Drew Faust had lovely colored chairs put on the lawn of the yard, so people just come and read or eat or talk in the yard.  The Memorial Church and Widener Library face each other and are really impressive; go during graduation and see the magic of the individuals who have worked so hard and their parents.

title: Spend some time here
text: So much history here.  Go on an official Harvard tour.  Spend some time in the Harvard yard and take it all in.  This is one of the most celebrated of American traditions.

title: Great View of Foliage in the Fall in Historic Setting
text: I've been to Harvard Yard a dozen times, but in October it is really special- the colors rival any Vermont tour you can take.  Avoid rubbing the statue of John Harvard for luck.  It is customary for students to urinate on it.

title: What a beautiful campus
text: Attended campus tour on 9/29/12 and even with the weather being a little cloudy/rainy we were so impressed by this campus and the town of Cambridge. What a beautiful place to attend college for 4 years.

title: Gorgeous campus
text: Definitely worth exploring when you visit.  We only walked/ran around, but it's a huge area with some open days, worth taking advantage of if/when you can.

title: Stately and academic halls.
text: I wandered around the halls while my step son took a student tour.  There was a lot of marble and lots of students.

title: Good ideas
text: I had not visited since the late 80's and the place is much more urbanized now, so the campus and the Square have lost the Boho vibe.  Still, it has everything you could want in terms of stores, the arts, and history.

title: Nice to visit
text: My wife and I spent just a few minutes here, as we were limited in time. I am sure it would have been much more interesting if we had taken a guided tour or at least spent some more time there. We had a nice visit and it is a very pastoral setting.

title: Nice buildings, but...
text: As a tourist, I went to walk around the Harvard campus and enjoyed seeing the campus buildings, however I was disappointed that it wasn't easy to find out the basic history about the buildings.  You could tell some were older than others and I would have loved to have known their history.

title: Harvard Yard
text: This is a must see if you are visting Boston.  So much history - unique place.  I loved walking around the entire complex and grounds

title: Student Led Tour at Harvard
text: We opted for the 'free', student led tour of Harvard - if you don't enjoy it, you don't pay; if you do, the recommended gratuity is $10.  Our tour was well worth the money. Guide 'Jess Lucy' poked fun at the 'Hahvahd' accent, and shared lots of 'inside' stories from the uni. She pointed out where all the famous graduates were housed, and told short, historical anecdotes at every turn.  Our group was around 20 people from all over the world. The full tour takes an hour and you walk 1.5 miles - at a very leisurely pace, with lots of stops.  A good way to see the campus.

title: Stare at Harvard students not studying
text: It's a campus courtyard.  There is a big statue of John Harvard, and in a good year he's wearing MIT's ring.  The yard was designed for through traffic - really not much to visit and not even the prettiest campus green space in town.

title: Harvard university
text: Because it is such a famous place, we were thrilled to be able to go to the campus and have a brief look around the grounds.  Very special.

title: Always a great campus to walk through
text: Always a nice campus to walk through.  They've done interesting things to keep it vibrant (chairs in quads, etc...).  There's a bit of construction going on, and sometimes can be problematic to navigate (especially in the rain)

title: Lovely on a sunny day
text: How many public spaces leave our garden chairs so there's somewhere to relax?  Great vibe with a mix of Harvard students, other locals and tourists, some trees for shade, and just a really nice place to chill for an hour or two on a nice day.

title: Beautiful and historic
text: I work here, so I am lucky to spend a lot of time walking through "The Yard". When the weather is nice you can sit in the colorful chairs on the lawn. It is open to the public and tours are available.

title: Pure awesomeness
text: The campus is beautiful in its austerity and history. The surrounding area teems with restaurants, clubs and boutiques. Everyone seems to be excited and happy in Harvard Square. No place like it in the US.

title: Not Worth It
text: If you are going for the architecture then skip it.  Unlike many historical universities around the world Harvard is very bland and boring in both an architectural and interest sense.  Sadly when we went we did not get to take in a tour (they start in mid Sept) which would have provided us with some history but as far as walking around the campus and checking out the architecture it was a total dud.

title: Harvard
text: Nice architecture. Nice info. session. Our tour was lacking in substance and we didn't see a great deal other than the architecture, and it was supposed to be an academic tour. We did see the foyer of the freshman cafeteria, but no classrooms, libraries, or dorms.

title: Harvard Univ tour by students
text: This tour is led by students - ours was extremely knowledgeable, with a great personality and delivery style.  We walked through the yard, and onto the extended campus.  Our guide was able to answer our questions and provide us with entertaining history and tid-bits.  The published cost is "free" but with a suggested tip of $10/pp or $20/per family - well worth it!  The tour is offered 7 days/wk Mar - Dec.

title: HavAHd YAHy
text: The sights, sounds, people, and stories within Harvard Yard are always amazing....take the Tour...get the real story about the oldest college in the US

title: Hahvard!!!
text: Fantastic history and everything you would expect of the place. Having 2 sons go there, I am biased. The only downer are the number of Asian tourists taking pictures of every squirrel on the campus.

title: Another institution worth seeing
text: An important university and a cool place to see. To me not as lovely as MIT but still a great sight to see.

title: Lovely for a wander on a sunny afternoon
text: Nice place to just wander through on a pleasant afternoon. Sunshine is a must to make this place look at its best. Square is bustling with street entertainers and offers a fantastic place to grab fro-yo (Pinkberry)

title: Interesting walk
text:
We went last weekend, which means moving in weekend for all the new and returning students. It was a lot of fun and very interesting to wander on the campus. Very nice students helped us find the Le Corbusier building, but we all had trouble finding the Gropius Building - unfortunately.
They offer free tours of the campus, run by student volunteers - the one we saw, was so passionate about sharing her stories of Harvard - she was great!

title: Myself1942
text: Wow, I understood that as a silly question. Don't you know Harvard University? Man it is well cherished all over the world for the last 400 years!

title: Lives up the the reputation
text: I spent several years there for Grad School.  It is worth a walk through.  You would then be able to say you "have gone to Harvard"  LOL.

title: So much to see and do
text: I spent two days moving my son into his dorm at Harvard.  Everyone was helpful and friendly.  I loved all the old buildings and learning about the history.

title: Moved my son into his Harvard dorm
text: Great experience!  Loved Harvard Square and touring Harvard Yard.  I look forward to coming back in October.  Weather was great!

title: Must see
text: I had an opportunity to tour this wonderful establishment and i was very impressed. Our guide told us stories of Conan Obrien and Bill gates and Mark Zuckerberg. The primal yell was awesome as well.  Its the oldest college in the States. If you get a chance take it.

title: Free tour of Harvard Yard by students
text:
Kids wanted to see Harvard and so do we. And even though I have downloaded free app and audiobook for the visit, having human guide is always better. Sam was just great - telling the facts in a very entertaining way and with a lot of jokes. Definitely worth the time spent!
I think this tour is organized by visitor center but maybe it is an initiative by students themselves.

title: Like in a movie
text: How can you not love Harvard. Place and people are great. Students are so lucky to live there, even if for a short period of their life. I bet it will be in their mind for the rest of their life.

title: Nice to See but not a "Don't Miss"
text: Very cool just to walk around, but it wasn't something I'd do again. I don't know anyone who attends/ed, but I enjoyed it nonetheless just for the historical perspective.

title: Interesting - better with Trip Advisor Guide
text: Walking through Harvard Yard and the entire campus is like strolling through history. If you don't know what you are looking at it could be quite boring. The best option is to download the Boston City Guide available free from Trip Advisor as an application on your smart phone or i-phone. The guide has a Harvard Yard guide that explains each building you are looking at with history and interesting facts. There is also an application called "Every Trail". You can download this too and it has guides as well as GPS driven with live maps. Also FREE and a Trip Advisor company.

title: Must see!
text: When in Boston, it is worth the small cab fare to visit Harvard. Grab a coffee from Starbucks and Walk around to get a feel for the area. Great cafes close by. Friendly people. Interesting sites.
i loved it , harvard is a great place to be around! great atmosphere and there are all different kinds of people that walk around there. its great for people watching

title: What a Marvel
text: A visit to Harvard's campus is a must do.  The history and the architecture are captivating.  Americans have every right to be so proud of this historic institution.

title: Such history, fascinating.
text: We could not believe it when we entered the grounds of such an amazing university with such history. We loved hearing the stories of John Harvard and the Library etc. Fascinating. Loved it. I understand you can walk around by yourself but really you would be doing yourself a misservice as we had a wonderful guide that gave us so much information that we would not have known otherwise, so please go with a guide. They bring it to life.

title: What a historical place
text: After a very interesting presentation we visited the campus with one of the students and heard the history of Harvard. It´s an amazing place, you feel the importance, knowledge and the history that surrounds you.

title: Enjoyable free history tour
text: I decided to go to visit Harvard after a recommendation from a friend. I'm glad I did as I found it a beautiful, interesting place. I went early and managed to get on a tour with a current student. I would definitely recommend this, as I think without it you would not appreciate the history of the site, or its relevance to the current students. It was also great to see some students moving in, and reminded you that this is still a working university, as well as a place steeped in history.

title: You can't park there
text: You can't park in Harvard Yard, but it's great to walk through and enjoy the history.  The Chapel has services some Sundays too.

title: Harvard tour led by students
text: Harvard students offered tours of campus.  My tour guide was very friendly and full of energy.   He showed us sights on campus including dorms where famous people resided.  Pretty short tour, I would have like to see more of the campus.   I wondered around for Abut another hour.

title: A nice walk through History
text: I really enjoy strolling through Harvard Yard, having read a great deal of history from the period when Harvard was established, it is amazing to think of what happened in this yard.  You are hanging out where some of the most famous people in history have likely had lunch, read the paper, perhaps stumbled back from a local pub...in fact you could be standing there right now with some of the famous people of tomorrow....and then, a really fun place, Harvard Square.

title: History!
text: There is a lot of history and wonderful stories here.  I recommend taking one of the student led tours to hear them.   Go to Holyoke Center or the vendors on the street outside.

title: Fun tour of "Hahvahd" led by current student
text: Our tour guide, Brie, was funny and could really project her voice, which is key to a good tour. My husband, teen and pre-teen daughters and I all enjoyed the tour. Interesting info, with only enough history to inform without overwhelming us with details.

title: Good Place to Walk Your Dog
text: Visit this place in the summer when the University is not in session.  It's a good place to read, relax, or walk the dog.

title: Harvard University
text: Harvard University is like any other large university campus.  There is nothing special about this location.  However, the shopping and restaurants around the campus are quite nice.

title: Inspirador...
text:
This place, buildings and garden are very nice and inspiring...
Nice and quite...

title: Enjoyable walk within the historical campus grounds
text:
Beautiful and peaceful campus. Gives you a glimpse of what student life is like in this historical place. We took a self-guided tour of Harvard using the free Harvard Yard Tour app, which provides a map plus helpful information on buildings of interest. The place is really worth a visit and easy to tour even without a map.

There were loads of tourists when we were there but that's probably because it was summer.

title: Whe-uh NAWT to Pahk yo-uh Cah
text: Beside being a Boston must-see, the Yard is a lovely urban enclosure--even if it's almost always busy with foot traffic.  Pat ol' John Harvard on the toe before you go.

title: Love IT!
text: We love all things Harvard!  Fantastice atmosphere...Harvard Square is where it is at :)

title: Beautiful Campus
text: We walked the campus and wandered in and out of Harvard Square. It was such a beautiful, peaceful area. I read a book on a lawn while my boyfriend fell asleep. And for July, the weather was so pleasant. The buildings are beautiful and it was so interesting to see the mixture of designs.

title: Not just for students
text: Even though you may not be able to get into Harvard, you can feel special being part of the Cambridge crowd.

title: One of the oldest universities in the US
text: It's really an experience visiting this university. Many coffee shops in the area. Great neighborhood.

title: Worth a stroll through
text: During May, we witnessed a game of frisbee, study sessions, students and professors milling about as we walked through the Yard.

title: A must see
text: Do not miss out on a quick visit to Haravard's commomns and its library.  The grounds are very nice and has a lot of history.  look at the river and see if you can spot any rowers.

title: Beautiful campus and great energy
text:
We really enjoyed our visit to Harvard.   The tour we took was helpful, fun & informative, and we got to experience the great energy of the students.  

I can't imagine what it must be like to be a student at this beautiful school, but I think there must be an annoying piece to have to dodge tourists while heading to class.  That being said, everyone we talked to was generous, kind, outgoing and warm.

It was a delightful visit and we recommend it.

title: Traditional and Historical
text: We had big expectations of what we thought Harvard would be like.  Needless to say, it is not one of the most beautiful campuses I have ever seen, it is not even in the top 10.  A prestigious school yes, and the surounding town is cute, but the campus itself was not as thrilling or exciting as we expected. I love its history and the buildings are old and somewhat charming, but the surround town and bookstore were more exciting.

title: We Recognize the Chair
text: Landscape Architect Mike Van Valkenburgh's lollipop-colored chairs are a welcome addition to the Yard, morphing this historic space into a people place.  We look forward to the transformation of Harvard Plaza currently under construction.

title: Harvard Plaza Construction
text: The world waits as Stoss Landscape Urbanism transforms the Plaza into a people place complete with free-form seating, copious bike racks and a seasonal pub.

title: Great place!
text: The university was beautiful and our student tour guide was helpful and informative. We enjoyed looking around the grounds and learning a little history about the school as well.

title: Just ok. :0/
text: I really expected better food. I've been to a multitude of restaurants and this was the average stuff they serve you at the moderately priced chain restaurants. The place was nice inside and what made the experience cool was that I was with friends. Otherwise the food was not worth the price. I agree with the other reviewer that the hill a few doors down looks shabbier, but has better tasting food. I'd prefer the better tasting food.

title: Nice area to visit
text:
Harvard and Harvard Sq. are definitely worth a visit.  Fun area 
Harvard Yard has many trees with brick buildings.  You can get a tour of the college in this area

title: Ivy School
text: Great school, just attended an information session on the school for undergraduate. Good list of concentrations to choose from and kids seem to be more relaxed then other schools  we visited.

title: Nice tour of university.
text: This was a nice tour of the university from the students perspective.  They suggest a donation for the family which is reasonable for getting more details of the campus.

title: great campus, people watching is fun here. check the museums

text: Harvard University offers students all they could ever ask or dream about as far as outstanding academics, extracurricular activities, political events, social gatherings, lifelong friendships, community involvement, and a terrific urban location.

title: A Taste of Harvard's Past and Present
text: Walking through Harvard Yard surrounded by the historic buildings, libraries, dorms, and greenery there is a magical feeling in the air. There is definitely a strong feeling of people and events from the past as you stroll about, however, watching the current students studying, chatting, and walking about going to classes or their activities is inspiring and exciting. The Harvard tours are very informative and the students leading the groups are very dedicated and will give you a good history lesson of the sites in the yard.

title: Awesome Place
